title: HYMN Α΄. TO DIONYSUS A΄
text: For some say, at Dracanum; and some, on windy Icarus; and some, in Naxos, O Heaven-born, Insewn; and others by the deep-eddying river Alpheus that pregnant Semele bare you to Zeus the thunder-lover.

title: HYMN Α΄. TO DIONYSUS A΄
text: And others yet, lord, say you were born in Thebes; but all these lie.

title: HYMN Α΄. TO DIONYSUS A΄
text: The Father of men and gods gave you birth remote from men and secretly from white-armed Hera.

spans.text: The Father of men and gods

title: HYMN Α΄. TO DIONYSUS A΄
text: There is a certain Nysa, a mountain most high and richly grown with woods, far off in Phoenice, near the streams of Aegyptus ... 'and men will lay up for her many offerings in her shrines. And as these things are three, so shall mortals ever sacrifice perfect hecatombs to you at your feasts each three years.' The Son of Cronos spoke and nodded with his dark brows.

spans.text: a mountain most high and richly grown with woods
men will lay up for her many offerings in her shrines
mortals ever sacrifice perfect hecatombs to you at your feasts each three years
spoke and nodded with his dark brows

title: HYMN Α΄. TO DIONYSUS A΄
text: And the divine locks of the king flowed forward from his immortal head, and he made great Olympus reel. So spake wise Zeus and ordained it with a nod.

spans.text: the divine locks of the king

title: HYMN Α΄. TO DIONYSUS A΄
text: Be favorable, O Insewn, Inspirer of frenzied women! we singers sing of you as we begin and as we end a strain, and none forgetting you may call holy song to mind.

spans.text: may call holy song to mind

title: HYMN Α΄. TO DIONYSUS A΄
text: And so, farewell, Dionysus, Insewn, with your mother Semele whom men call Thyone.

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: I begin to sing of rich-haired Demeter, awful goddess — of her and her trim-ankled daughter whom Aidoneus rapt away, given to him by all-seeing Zeus the loud-thunderer.

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: Apart from Demeter, lady of the golden sword and glorious fruits, she was playing with the deep-bosomed daughters of Oceanus and gathering flowers over a soft meadow, roses and crocuses and beautiful violets, irises also and hyacinths and the narcissus, which Earth made to grow at the will of Zeus and to please the Host of Many, to be a snare for the bloom-like girl — a marvellous, radiant flower.

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: It was a thing of awe whether for deathless gods or mortal men to see: from its root grew a hundred blooms and it smelled most sweetly, so that all wide heaven above and the whole earth and the sea's salt swell laughed for joy.

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: And the girl was amazed and reached out with both hands to take the lovely toy; but the wide-pathed earth yawned there in the plain of Nysa, and the lord, Host of Many, with his immortal horses sprang out upon her — the Son of Cronos, He who has many names.

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: He caught her up reluctant on his golden car and bare her away lamenting.

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: Then she cried out shrilly with her voice, calling upon her father, the Son of Cronos, who is most high and excellent.

spans.text: she cried out shrilly with her voice
who is most high and excellent

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: But no one, either of the deathless gods or of mortal men, heard her voice, nor yet the olive-trees bearing rich fruit: only tender-hearted Hecate, bright-coiffed, the daughter of Persaeus, heard the girl from her cave, and the lord Helios, Hyperion's bright son, as she cried to her father, the Son of Cronos.

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: But he was sitting aloof, apart from the gods, in his temple where many pray, and receiving sweet offerings from mortal men.

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: So he, that son of Cronos, of many names, who is Ruler of Many and Host of Many, was bearing her away by leave of Zeus on his immortal chariot — his own brother's child and all unwilling.

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: And so long as she, the goddess, yet beheld earth and starry heaven and the strong-flowing sea where fishes shoal, and the rays of the sun, and still hoped to see her dear mother and the tribes of the eternal gods, so long hope calmed her great heart for all her trouble⋯and the heights of the mountains and the depths of the sea rang with her immortal voice: and her queenly mother heard her.

spans.text: the tribes of the eternal gods

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: Bitter pain seized her heart, and she rent the covering upon her divine hair with her dear hands: her dark cloak she cast down from both her shoulders and sped, like a wild-bird, over the firm land and yielding sea, seeking her child.

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: But no one would tell her the truth, neither god nor mortal man; and of the birds of omen none came with true news for her.

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: Then for nine days queenly Deo wandered over the earth with flaming torches in her hands, so grieved that she never tasted ambrosia and the sweet draught of nectar, nor sprinkled her body with water.

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: But when the tenth enlightening dawn had come, Hecate, with a torch in her hands, met her, and spoke to her and told her news: 'Queenly Demeter, bringer of seasons and giver of good gifts, what god of heaven or what mortal man has rapt away Persephone and pierced with sorrow your dear heart? For I heard her voice, yet saw not with my eyes who it was. But I tell you truly and shortly all I know.' So, then, said Hecate.

spans.text: I tell you truly and shortly all I know

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: And the daughter of rich-haired Rhea answered her not, but sped swiftly with her, holding flaming torches in her hands.

spans.text: holding flaming torches in her hands

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: So they came to Helios, who is watchman of both gods and men, and stood in front of his horses: and the bright goddess enquired of him: 'Helios, do you at least regard me, goddess as I am, if ever by word or deed of mine I have cheered your heart and spirit. Through the fruitless air I heard the thrilling cry of my daughter whom I bare, sweet scion of my body and lovely in form, as of one seized violently; though with my eyes I saw nothing. But you — for with your beams you look down from the bright upper air over all the earth and sea — tell me truly of my dear child, if you have seen her anywhere, what god or mortal man has violently seized her against her will and mine, and so made off.' So said she.

spans.text: watchman of both gods and men
violently seized her against her will and mine

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: And the Son of Hyperion answered her: 'Queen Demeter, daughter of rich-haired Rhea, I will tell you the truth; for I greatly reverence and pity you in your grief for your trim-ankled daughter. None other of the deathless gods is to blame, but only cloud-gathering Zeus who gave her to Hades, her father's brother, to be called his buxom wife. And Hades seized her and took her loudly crying in his chariot down to his realm of mist and gloom. Yet, goddess, cease your loud lament and keep not vain anger unrelentingly: Aidoneus, the Ruler of Many, is no unfitting husband among the deathless gods for your child, being your own brother and born of the same stock: also, for honor, he has that third share which he received when division was made at the first, and is appointed lord of those among whom he dwells.' So he spake, and called to his horses: and at his chiding they quickly whirled the swift chariot along, like long-winged birds.

spans.text: division was made at the first
lord of those among whom he dwells

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: But grief yet more terrible and savage came into the heart of Demeter, and thereafter she was so angered with the dark-clouded Son of Cronos that she avoided the gathering of the gods and high Olympus, and went to the towns and rich fields of men, disfiguring her form a long while.

spans.text: grief yet more terrible and savage
angered with the dark-clouded Son of Cronos
towns and rich fields of men

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: And no one of men or deep-bosomed women knew her when they saw her, until she came to the house of wise Celeus who then was lord of fragrant Eleusis.

spans.text: no one of men or deep-bosomed women

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: Vexed in her dear heart, she sat near the wayside by the Maiden Well, from which the women of the place were used to draw water, in a shady place over which grew an olive shrub.

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: And she was like an ancient woman who is cut off from childbearing and the gifts of garland-loving Aphrodite, like the nurses of kings' children who deal justice, or like the house-keepers in their echoing halls.

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: There the daughters of Celeus, son of Eleusis, saw her, as they were coming for easy-drawn water, to carry it in pitchers of bronze to their dear father's house: four were they and like goddesses in the flower of their girlhood, Callidice and Cleisidice and lovely Demo and Callithoë who was the eldest of them all.

spans.text: in the flower of their girlhood
who was the eldest of them all

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: They knew her not — for the gods are not easily discerned by mortals — but standing near by her spoke winged words: 'Old mother, whence and who are you of folk born long ago? Why are you gone away from the city and do not draw near the houses? For there in the shady halls are women of just such age as you, and others younger; and they would welcome you both by word and by deed.' Thus they said.

spans.text: women of just such age as you
they would welcome you both by word and by deed

title: HYMN B΄. TO DEMETER A΄
text: And she, that queen among goddesses answered them saying: 'Hail, dear children, whosoever you are of woman-kind. I will tell you my story; for it is not unseemly that I should tell you truly what you ask. Doso is my name, for my stately mother gave it me. And now I am come from Crete over the sea's wide back — not willingly; but against my liking, by force of strength, pirates brought me thence. Afterwards they put in with their swift craft to Thoricus, and there the women landed on the shore in full throng and the men likewise, and they began to make ready a meal by the stern-cables of the ship. But my heart craved not pleasant food, and I fled secretly across the dark country and escaped my masters, that they should not take me unpurchased across the sea, there to win a price for me. And so I wandered and am come here: and I know not at all what land this is or what people are in it. But may all those who dwell on Olympus give you husbands and birth of children as parents desire, so you take pity on me, maidens, ...'

spans.text: my heart craved not pleasant food

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: I will remember and not be unmindful of Apollo who shoots afar.

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: As he goes through the house of Zeus, the gods tremble before him and all spring up from their seats when he draws near, as he bends his bright bow.

spans.text: all spring up from their seats

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: But Leto alone stays by the side of Zeus who delights in thunder; and then she unstrings his bow, and closes his quiver, and takes his archery from his strong shoulders in her hands and hangs them on a golden peg against a pillar of his father's house.

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: Then she leads him to a seat and makes him sit: and the Father gives him nectar in a golden cup welcoming his dear son, while the other gods make him sit down there, and queenly Leto rejoices because she bare a mighty son and an archer.

spans.text: she leads him to a seat

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: Rejoice, blessed Leto, for you bare glorious children, the lord Apollo and Artemis who delights in arrows; her in Ortygia, and him in rocky Delos, as you rested against the great mass of the Cynthian hill hard by a palm-tree by the streams of Inopus.

spans.text: the great mass of the Cynthian hill

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: How, then, shall I sing of you who in all ways are a worthy theme of song.

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: For everywhere, O Phoebus, the whole range of song is fallen to you, both over the mainland that rears heifers and over the isles.

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: All mountain-peaks and high headlands of lofty hills and rivers flowing out to the deep and beaches sloping seawards and havens of the sea are your delight.

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: Shall I sing how at the first Leto bare you to be the joy of men, as she rested against Mount Cynthus in that rocky isle, in sea-girt Delos — while on either hand a dark wave rolled on landwards driven by shrill winds — whence arising you rule over all mortal men.

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: Among those who are in Crete, and in the township of Athens, and in the isle of Aegina and Euboea, famous for ships, in Aegae and Eiresiae and Peparethus near the sea, in Thracian Athos and Pelion's towering heights and Thracian Samos and the shady hills of Ida, in Scyros and Phocaea and the high hill of Autocane and fair-lying Imbros and smouldering Lemnos and rich Lesbos, home of Macar, the son of Aeolus, and Chios, brightest of all the isles that lie in the sea, and craggy Mimas and the heights of Corycus and gleaming Claros and the sheer hill of Aesagea and watered Samos and the steep heights of Mycale, in Miletus and Cos, the city of Meropian men, and steep Cnidos and windy Carpathos, in Naxos and Paros and rocky Rhenaea — so far roamed Leto in travail with the god who shoots afar, to see if any land would be willing to make a dwelling for her son.

spans.text: brightest of all the isles that lie in the sea

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: But they greatly trembled and feared, and none, not even the richest of them, dared receive Phoebus, until queenly Leto set foot on Delos and uttered winged words and asked her: 'Delos, if you would be willing to be the abode of my son Phoebus Apollo and make him a rich temple — for no other will touch you, as you will find: and I think you will never be rich in oxen and sheep, nor bear vintage nor yet produce plants abundantly. But if you have the temple of far-shooting Apollo, all men will bring you hecatombs and gather here, and incessant savour of rich sacrifice will always arise, and you will feed those who dwell in you from the hand of strangers; for truly your own soil is not rich.' So spake Leto.

spans.text: none, not even the richest of them
abode of my son Phoebus Apollo
never be rich in oxen and sheep
all men will bring you hecatombs
feed those who dwell in you from the hand of strangers
your own soil is not rich

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: And Delos rejoiced and answered and said: 'Leto, most glorious daughter of great Coeus, joyfully would I receive your child the far-shooting lord; for it is all too true that I am ill-spoken of among men, whereas thus I should become very greatly honored. But this saying I fear, and I will not hide it from you, Leto. They say that Apollo will be one that is very haughty and will greatly lord it among gods and men all over the fruitful earth. Therefore, I greatly fear in heart and spirit that as soon as he sees the light of the sun, he will scorn this island — for truly I have but a hard, rocky soil — and overturn me and thrust me down with his feet in the depths of the sea; then will the great ocean wash deep above my head for ever, and he will go to another land such as will please him, there to make his temple and wooded groves. So many-footed creatures of the sea will make their lairs in me and black seals their dwellings undisturbed, because I lack people. Yet if you will but dare to swear a great oath, goddess, that here first he will build a glorious temple to be an oracle for men, then let him afterwards make temples and wooded groves amongst all men; for surely he will be greatly renowned.' So said Delos.

spans.text: most glorious daughter of great Coeus

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: And Leto swear the great oath of the gods: 'Now hear this, Earth and wide Heaven above, and dropping water of Styx (this is the strongest and most awful oath for the blessed gods), surely Phoebus shall have here his fragrant altar and precinct, and you he shall honor above all.'

spans.text: the great oath of the gods
the strongest and most awful oath
you he shall honor above all

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: Now when Leto had sworn and ended her oath, Delos was very glad at the birth of the far-shooting lord.

spans.text: the birth of the far-shooting lord

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: But Leto was racked nine days and nine nights with pangs beyond wont.

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: And there were with her all the chiefest of the goddesses, Dione and Rhea and Ichnaea and Themis and loud-moaning Amphitrite and the other deathless goddesses save white-armed Hera, who sat in the halls of cloud-gathering Zeus.

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: Only Eilithyia, goddess of sore travail, had not heard of Leto's trouble, for she sat on the top of Olympus beneath golden clouds by white-armed Hera's contriving, who kept her close through envy, because Leto with the lovely tresses was soon to bear a son faultless and strong.

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: But the goddesses sent out Iris from the well-set isle to bring Eilithyia, promising her a great necklace strung with golden threads, nine cubits long.

spans.text: a great necklace strung with golden threads

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: And they bade Iris call her aside from white-armed Hera, lest she might afterwards turn her from coming with her words.

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: When swift Iris, fleet of foot as the wind, had heard all this, she set to run; and quickly finishing all the distance she came to the home of the gods, sheer Olympus, and forthwith called Eilithyia out from the hall to the door and spoke winged words to her, telling her all as the goddesses who dwell on Olympus had bidden her.

spans.text: fleet of foot as the wind
the goddesses who dwell on Olympus

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: So she moved the heart of Eilithyia in her dear breast; and they went their way, like shy wild-doves in their going.

spans.text: she moved the heart of Eilithyia in her dear breast

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: And as soon as Eilithyia the goddess of sore travail set foot on Delos, the pains of birth seized Leto, and she longed to bring forth; so she cast her arms about a palm tree and kneeled on the soft meadow while the earth laughed for joy beneath.

spans.text: cast her arms about a palm tree

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: Then the child leaped forth to the light, and all the goddesses raised a cry.

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: Straightway, great Phoebus, the goddesses washed you purely and cleanly with sweet water, and swathed you in a white garment of fine texture, new-woven, and fastened a golden band about you.

spans.text: a white garment of fine texture

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: Now Leto did not give Apollo, bearer of the golden blade, her breast; but Themis duly poured nectar and ambrosia with her divine hands: and Leto was glad because she had borne a strong son and an archer.

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: But as soon as you had tasted that divine heavenly food, O Phoebus, you could no longer then be held by golden cords nor confined with bands, but all their ends were undone.

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: Forth-with Phoebus Apollo spoke out among the deathless goddesses: 'The lyre and the curved bow shall ever be dear to me, and I will declare to men the unfailing will of Zeus.' So said Phoebus, the long-haired god who shoots afar and began to walk upon the wide-pathed earth; and all the goddesses were amazed at him.

spans.text: The lyre and the curved bow

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: Then with gold all Delos [was laden, beholding the child of Zeus and Leto, for joy because the god chose her above the islands and shore to make his dwelling in her: and she loved him yet more in her heart] blossomed as does a mountain-top with woodland flowers.

spans.text: the child of Zeus and Leto

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: And you, O lord Apollo, god of the silver bow, shooting afar, now walked on craggy Cynthus, and now kept wandering about the islands and the people in them.

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO DELIAN AND PYTHIAN APOLLO
text: Many are your temples and wooded groves, and all peaks and towering bluffs.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: Muse, sing of Hermes, the son of Zeus and Maia, lord of Cyllene and Arcadia rich in flocks, the luck-bringing messenger of the immortals whom Maia bare, the rich-tressed nymph, when she was joined in love with Zeus, — a shy goddess, for she avoided the company of the blessed gods, and lived within a deep, shady cave.

spans.text: the son of Zeus and Maia
lord of Cyllene and Arcadia rich in flocks
the luck-bringing messenger of the immortals
when she was joined in love with Zeus
the company of the blessed gods

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: There the son of Cronos used to lie with the rich-tressed nymph, unseen by deathless gods and mortal men, at dead of night while sweet sleep should hold white-armed Hera fast.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: And when the purpose of great Zeus was fulfilled, and the tenth moon with her was fixed in heaven, she was delivered and a notable thing was come to pass.

spans.text: a notable thing was come to pass

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: For then she bare a son, of many shifts, blandly cunning, a robber, a cattle driver, a bringer of dreams, a watcher by night, a thief at the gates, one who was soon to show forth wonderful deeds among the deathless gods.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: Born with the dawning, at mid-day he played on the lyre, and in the evening he stole the cattle of far-shooting Apollo on the fourth day of the month; for on that day queenly Maia bare him.

spans.text: he stole the cattle of far-shooting Apollo

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: So soon as he had leaped from his mother's heavenly womb, he lay not long waiting in his holy cradle, but he sprang up and sought the oxen of Apollo.

spans.text: leaped from his mother's heavenly womb
he lay not long waiting in his holy cradle

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: But as he stepped over the threshold of the high-roofed cave, he found a tortoise there and gained endless delight.

spans.text: he stepped over the threshold of the high-roofed cave

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: For it was Hermes who first made the tortoise a singer.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: The creature fell in his way at the courtyard gate, where it was feeding on the rich grass before the dwelling, waddling along.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: When he saw it, the luck-bringing son of Zeus laughed and said: 'An omen of great luck for me so soon. I do not slight it. Hail, comrade of the feast, lovely in shape, sounding at the dance. With joy I meet you. Where got you that rich gaud for covering, that spangled shell — a tortoise living in the mountains. But I will take and carry you within: you shall help me and I will do you no disgrace, though first of all you must profit me. It is better to be at home: harm may come out of doors. Living, you shall be a spell against mischievous witchcraft; but if you die, then you shall make sweetest song.

spans.text: harm may come out of doors

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: Thus speaking, he took up the tortoise in both hands and went back into the house carrying his charming toy.

spans.text: he took up the tortoise in both hands

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: Then he cut off its limbs and scooped out the marrow of the mountain-tortoise with a scoop of grey iron.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: As a swift thought darts through the heart of a man when thronging cares haunt him, or as bright glances flash from the eye, so glorious Hermes planned both thought and deed at once.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: He cut stalks of reed to measure and fixed them, fastening their ends across the back and through the shell of the tortoise, and then stretched ox hide all over it by his skill.

spans.text: stretched ox hide all over it

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: Also he put in the horns and fitted a cross-piece upon the two of them, and stretched seven strings of sheep-gut.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: But when he had made it he proved each string in turn with the key, as he held the lovely thing.

spans.text: he proved each string in turn with the key

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: At the touch of his hand it sounded marvelously; and, as he tried it, the god sang sweet random snatches, even as youths bandy taunts at festivals.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: He sang of Zeus the son of Cronos and neat-shod Maia, the converse which they had before in the comradeship of love, telling all the glorious tale of his own begetting.

spans.text: the converse which they had before in the comradeship of love
the glorious tale of his own begetting

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: He celebrated, too, the handmaids of the nymph, and her bright home, and the tripods all about the house, and the abundant cauldrons.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: But while he was singing of all these, his heart was bent on other matters.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: And he took the hollow lyre and laid it in his sacred cradle, and sprang from the sweet-smelling hall to a watch-place, pondering sheer trickery in his heart — deeds such as knavish folk pursue in the dark night-time; for he longed to taste flesh.

spans.text: deeds such as knavish folk pursue in the dark night-time

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: The Sun was going down beneath the earth towards Ocean with his horses and chariot when Hermes came hurrying to the shadowy mountains of Pieria, where the divine cattle of the blessed gods had their steads and grazed the pleasant, unmown meadows.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: Of these the Son of Maia, the sharp-eyed slayer of Argus then cut off from the herd fifty loud-lowing kine, and drove them straggling-wise across a sandy place, turning their hoof-prints aside.

spans.text: cut off from the herd fifty loud-lowing kine

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: Also, he bethought him of a crafty ruse and reversed the marks of their hoofs, making the front behind and the hind before, while he himself walked the other way.

spans.text: he bethought him of a crafty ruse
reversed the marks of their hoofs
the front behind and the hind before
he himself walked the other way

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: Then he wove sandals with wicker-work by the sand of the sea, wonderful things, unthought of, unimagined; for he mixed together tamarisk and myrtle-twigs, fastening together an armful of their fresh, young wood, and tied them, leaves and all securely under his feet as light sandals.

spans.text: an armful of their fresh, young wood

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: That brushwood the glorious Slayer of Argus plucked in Pieria as he was preparing for his journey, making shift as one making haste for a long journey.

spans.text: he was preparing for his journey
making shift as one making haste for a long journey

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: But an old man tilling his flowering vineyard saw him as he was hurrying down the plain through grassy Onchestus.

spans.text: he was hurrying down the plain

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: So the Son of Maia began and said to him: 'Old man, digging about your vines with bowed shoulders, surely you shall have much wine when all these bear fruit, if you obey me and strictly remember not to have seen what you have seen, and not to have heard what you have heard, and to keep silent when nothing of your own is harmed.'

spans.text: remember not to have seen what you have seen
not to have heard what you have heard
nothing of your own is harmed

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: When he had said this much, he hurried the strong cattle on together: through many shadowy mountains and echoing gorges and flowery plains glorious Hermes drove them.

spans.text: he hurried the strong cattle on together

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: And now the divine night, his dark ally, was mostly passed, and dawn that sets folk to work was quickly coming on, while bright Selene, daughter of the lord Pallas, Megamedes' son, had just climbed her watch-post, when the strong Son of Zeus drove the wide-browed cattle of Phoebus Apollo to the river Alpheus.

spans.text: dawn that sets folk to work
the wide-browed cattle of Phoebus Apollo

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: And they came unwearied to the high-roofed byres and the drinking-troughs that were before the noble meadow.

spans.text: that were before the noble meadow

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: Then, after he had well-fed the loud-bellowing cattle with fodder and driven them into the byre, close-packed and chewing lotus and dewy galingal, he gathered a pile of wood and began to seek the art of fire.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: He chose a stout laurel branch and trimmed it with the knife held firmly in his hand: and the hot smoke rose up.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: For it was Hermes who first invented fire-sticks and fire.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: Next he took many dried sticks and piled them thick and plenty in a sunken trench: and flame began to glow, spreading afar the blast of fierce-burning fire.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: And while the strength of glorious Hephaestus was beginning to kindle the fire, he dragged out two lowing, horned cows close to the fire; for great strength was with him.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: He threw them both panting upon their backs on the ground, and rolled them on their sides, bending their necks over, and pierced their vital chord.

spans.text: He threw them both panting upon their backs on the ground

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: Then he went on from task to task: first he cut up the rich, fatted meat, and pierced it with wooden spits, and roasted flesh and the honorable chine and the paunch full of dark blood all together.

spans.text: he went on from task to task
first he cut up the rich, fatted meat
and pierced it with wooden spits
the paunch full of dark blood

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: He laid them there upon the ground, and spread out the hides on a rugged rock: and so they are still there many ages afterwards, a long, long time after all this, and are continually.

spans.text: a long, long time after all this

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: Next glad-hearted Hermes dragged the rich meats he had prepared and put them on a smooth, flat stone, and divided them into twelve portions distributed by lot, making each portion wholly honorable.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: Then glorious Hermes longed for the sacrificial meat, for the sweet savour wearied him, god though he was; nevertheless his proud heart was not prevailed upon to devour the flesh, although he greatly desired.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: But he put away in the high-roofed byre the fat and all the flesh, placing them high up to be a token of his youthful theft.

spans.text: a token of his youthful theft

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: And after that he gathered dry sticks and utterly destroyed with fire all the hoofs and all the heads.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: And when the god had duly finished all, he threw his sandals into deep-eddying Alpheus, and quenched the embers, covering the black ashes with sand, and so spent the night while Selene's soft light shone down.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO HERMES Α΄
text: Then the god went straight back again at dawn to the bright crests of Cyllene, and no one met him on the long journey either of the blessed gods or mortal men...

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: Muse, tell me the deeds of golden Aphrodite the Cyprian, who stirs up sweet passion in the gods and subdues the tribes of mortal men and birds that fly in air and all the many creatures that the dry land rears, and all that the sea: all these love the deeds of rich-crowned Cytherea.

spans.text: the deeds of golden Aphrodite the Cyprian
the many creatures that the dry land rears

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: Yet there are three hearts that she cannot bend nor yet ensnare.

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: First is the daughter of Zeus who holds the aegis, bright-eyed Athena; for she has no pleasure in the deeds of golden Aphrodite, but delights in wars and in the work of Ares, in strifes and battles and in preparing famous crafts.

spans.text: no pleasure in the deeds of golden Aphrodite

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: She first taught earthly craftsmen to make chariots of war and cars variously wrought with bronze, and she, too, teaches tender maidens in the house and puts knowledge of goodly arts in each one's mind.

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: Nor does laughter-loving Aphrodite ever tame in love Artemis, the huntress with shafts of gold; for she loves archery and the slaying of wild beasts in the mountains, the lyre also and dancing and thrilling cries and shady woods and the cities of upright men.

spans.text: the huntress with shafts of gold

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: Nor yet does the pure maiden Hestia love Aphrodite's works.

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: She was the first-born child of wily Cronos and youngest too, by will of Zeus who holds the aegis, — a queenly maid whom both Poseidon and Apollo sought to wed.

spans.text: the first-born child of wily Cronos
by will of Zeus who holds the aegis

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: But she was wholly unwilling, nay, stubbornly refused; and touching the head of father Zeus who holds the aegis, she, that fair goddess, swear a great oath which has in truth been fulfilled, that she would be a maiden all her days.

spans.text: which has in truth been fulfilled
she would be a maiden all her days

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: So Zeus the Father gave her an high honor instead of marriage, and she has her place in the midst of the house and has the richest portion.

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: In all the temples of the gods she has a share of honor, and among all mortal men she is chief of the goddesses.

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: Of these three Aphrodite cannot bend or ensnare the hearts.

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: But of all others there is nothing among the blessed gods or among mortal men that has escaped Aphrodite.

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: Even the heart of Zeus, who delights in thunder, is led astray by her; though he is greatest of all and has the lot of highest majesty, she beguiles even his wise heart whensoever she pleases, and mates him with mortal women, unknown to Hera, his sister and his wife, the grandest far in beauty among the deathless goddesses —most glorious is she whom wily Cronos with her mother Rhea did beget: and Zeus, whose wisdom is everlasting, made her his chaste and careful wife.

spans.text: the grandest far in beauty among the deathless goddesses

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: But upon Aphrodite herself Zeus cast sweet desire to be joined in love with a mortal man, to the end that, very soon, not even she should be innocent of a mortal's love; lest laughter-loving Aphrodite should one day softly smile and say mockingly among all the gods that she had joined the gods in love with mortal women who bare sons of death to the deathless gods, and had mated the goddesses with mortal men.

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: And so he put in her heart sweet desire for Anchises who at that time among the steep hills of many-fountained Ida was tending cattle, and in shape was like the immortal gods.

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: Therefore, when laughter-loving Aphrodite saw him, she loved him, and terribly desire seized her in her heart.

spans.text: terribly desire seized her in her heart

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: She went to Cyprus, to Paphos, where her precinct is and fragrant altar, and passed into her sweet-smelling temple.

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: There she went in and put to the glittering doors, and there the Graces bathed her with heavenly oil such as blooms upon the bodies of the eternal gods — oil divinely sweet, which she had by her, filled with fragrance.

spans.text: the bodies of the eternal gods

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: And laughter-loving Aphrodite put on all her rich clothes, and when she had decked herself with gold, she left sweet-smelling Cyprus and went in haste towards Troy, swiftly travelling high up among the clouds.

spans.text: swiftly travelling high up among the clouds

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: So she came to many-fountained Ida, the mother of wild creatures and went straight to the homestead across the mountains.

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: After her came grey wolves, fawning on her, and grim-eyed lions, and bears, and fleet leopards, ravenous for deer: and she was glad in heart to see them, and put desire in their breasts, so that they all mated, two together, about the shadowy coombes.

spans.text: she was glad in heart to see them

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: But she herself came to the neat-built shelters, and him she found left quite alone in the homestead — the hero Anchises who was comely as the gods.

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: All the others were following the herds over the grassy pastures, and he, left quite alone in the homestead, was roaming hither and thither and playing thrillingly upon the lyre.

spans.text: left quite alone in the homestead

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: And Aphrodite, the daughter of Zeus stood before him, being like a pure maiden in height and mien, that he should not be frightened when he took heed of her with his eyes.

spans.text: when he took heed of her with his eyes

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: Now when Anchises saw her, he marked her well and wondered at her mien and height and shining garments.

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: For she was clad in a robe out-shining the brightness of fire, a splendid robe of gold, enriched with all manner of needlework, which shimmered like the moon over her tender breasts, a marvel to see.

spans.text: enriched with all manner of needlework

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: Also she wore twisted brooches and shining earrings in the form of flowers; and round her soft throat were lovely necklaces.

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: And Anchises was seized with love, and said to her: 'Hail, lady, whoever of the blessed ones you are that are come to this house, whether Artemis, or Leto, or golden Aphrodite, or high-born Themis, or bright-eyed Athena. Or, maybe, you are one of the Graces come hither, who bear the gods company and are called immortal, or else one of the Nymphs who haunt the pleasant woods, or of those who inhabit this lovely mountain and the springs of rivers and grassy meads. I will make you an altar upon a high peak in a far seen place, and will sacrifice rich offerings to you at all seasons. And do you feel kindly towards me and grant that I may become a man very eminent among the Trojans, and give me strong offspring for the time to come. As for my own self, let me live long and happily, seeing the light of the sun, and come to the threshold of old age, a man prosperous among the people.'

spans.text: a man very eminent among the Trojans
a man prosperous among the people

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO APHRODITE Α΄
text: Thereupon Aphrodite the daughter of Zeus answered him: 'Anchises, most glorious of all men born on earth, know that I am no goddess: why do you liken me to the deathless ones. Nay, I am but a mortal, and a woman was the mother that bare me. Otreus of famous name is my father, if so be you have heard of him, and he reigns over all Phrygia rich in fortresses. But I know your speech well beside my own, for a Trojan nurse brought me up at home: she took me from my dear mother and reared me thenceforth when I was a little child. So comes it, then, that I well know your tongue also. And now the Slayer of Argus with the golden wand has caught me up from the dance of huntress Artemis, her with the golden arrows. For there were many of us, nymphs and marriageable  maidens, playing together; and an innumerable company encircled us: from these the Slayer of Argus with the golden wand rapt me away. He carried me over many fields of mortal men and over much land untilled and unpossessed, where savage wild-beasts roam through shady coombes, until I thought never again to touch the life-giving earth with my feet. And he said that I should be called the wedded wife of Anchises, and should bear you goodly children. But when he had told and advised me, he, the strong Slayer of Argos, went back to the families of the deathless gods...

spans.text: most glorious of all men born on earth
the families of the deathless gods

title: HYMN Ϛ΄. TO APHRODITE Β΄
text: I will sing of stately Aphrodite, gold-crowned and beautiful, whose dominion is the walled cities of all sea-set Cyprus.

title: HYMN Ϛ΄. TO APHRODITE Β΄
text: There the moist breath of the western wind wafted her over the waves of the loud-moaning sea in soft foam, and there the gold-filleted Hours welcomed her joyously.

spans.text: the moist breath of the western wind
wafted her over the waves of the loud-moaning sea
the waves of the loud-moaning sea

title: HYMN Ϛ΄. TO APHRODITE Β΄
text: They clothed her with heavenly garments: on her head they put a fine, well-wrought crown of gold, and in her pierced ears they hung ornaments of orichalc and precious gold, and adorned her with golden necklaces over her soft neck and snow-white breasts, jewels which the gold-filleted Hours wear themselves whenever they go to their father's house to join the lovely dances of the gods.

spans.text: ornaments of orichalc and precious gold

title: HYMN Ϛ΄. TO APHRODITE Β΄
text: And when they had fully decked her, they brought her to the gods, who welcomed her when they saw her, giving her their hands.

spans.text: they brought her to the gods

title: HYMN Ϛ΄. TO APHRODITE Β΄
text: Each one of them prayed that he might lead her home to be his wedded wife, so greatly were they amazed at the beauty of violet-crowned Cytherea.

title: HYMN Ϛ΄. TO APHRODITE Β΄
text: Hail, sweetly-winning, coy-eyed goddess.

title: HYMN Ϛ΄. TO APHRODITE Β΄
text: Grant that I may gain the victory in this contest, and order you my song.

title: HYMN Ϛ΄. TO APHRODITE Β΄
text: And now I will remember you and another song also.

title: HYMN Ζ΄. TO DIONYSIS B΄
text: I will tell of Dionysus, the son of glorious Semele, how he appeared on a jutting headland by the shore of the fruitless sea, seeming like a stripling in the first flush of manhood: his rich, dark hair was waving about him, and on his strong shoulders he wore a purple robe

title: HYMN Ζ΄. TO DIONYSIS B΄
text: Presently there came swiftly over the sparkling sea Tyrsenian pirates on a well-decked ship — a miserable doom led them on.

title: HYMN Ζ΄. TO DIONYSIS B΄
text: When they saw him they made signs to one another and sprang out quickly, and seizing him straightway put him on board their ship exultingly; for they thought him the son of heaven-nurtured kings.

title: HYMN Ζ΄. TO DIONYSIS B΄
text: They sought to bind him with rude bonds, but the bonds would not hold him, and the withes fell far away from his hands and feet: and he sat with a smile in his dark eyes.

spans.text: They sought to bind him with rude bonds
fell far away from his hands and feet
he sat with a smile in his dark eyes
a smile in his dark eyes

title: HYMN Ζ΄. TO DIONYSIS B΄
text: Then the helmsman understood all and cried out at once to his fellows and said: 'Madmen, what god is this whom you have taken and bind, strong that he is. Not even the well-built ship can carry him. Surely this is either Zeus or Apollo who has the silver bow, or Poseidon, for he looks not like mortal men but like the gods who dwell on Olympus. Come, then, let us set him free upon the dark shore at once: do not lay hands on him, lest he grow angry and stir up dangerous winds and heavy squalls.'. So said he.

spans.text: whom you have taken and bind
Come, then, let us set him free
do not lay hands on him

title: HYMN Ζ΄. TO DIONYSIS B΄
text: But the master chid him with taunting words: 'Madman, mark the wind and help hoist sail on the ship: catch all the sheets. As for this fellow we men will see to him: I reckon he is bound for Egypt or for Cyprus or to the Hyperboreans or further still. But in the end he will speak out and tell us his friends and all his wealth and his brothers, now that providence has thrown him in our way.'

title: HYMN Ζ΄. TO DIONYSIS B΄
text: When he had said this, he had mast and sail hoisted on the ship, and the wind filled the sail and the crew hauled taut the sheets on either side.

spans.text: he had mast and sail hoisted on the ship
hauled taut the sheets on either side

title: HYMN Ζ΄. TO DIONYSIS B΄
text: But soon strange things were seen among them.

title: HYMN Ζ΄. TO DIONYSIS B΄
text: First of all sweet, fragrant wine ran streaming throughout all the black ship and a heavenly smell arose, so that all the seamen were seized with amazement when they saw it.

title: HYMN Ζ΄. TO DIONYSIS B΄
text: And all at once a vine spread out both ways along the top of the sail with many clusters hanging down from it, and a dark ivy-plant twined about the mast, blossoming with flowers, and with rich berries growing on it; and all the thole-pins were covered with garlands.

title: HYMN Ζ΄. TO DIONYSIS B΄
text: When the pirates saw all this, then at last they bade the helmsman to put the ship to land.

title: HYMN Ζ΄. TO DIONYSIS B΄
text: But the god changed into a dreadful lion there on the ship, in the bows, and roared loudly: amidships also he showed his wonders and created a shaggy bear which stood up ravening, while on the forepeak was the lion glaring fiercely with scowling brows.

title: HYMN Ζ΄. TO DIONYSIS B΄
text: And so the sailors fled into the stern and crowded bemused about the right-minded helmsman, until suddenly the lion sprang upon the master and seized him; and when the sailors saw it they leapt out overboard one and all into the bright sea, escaping from a miserable fate, and were changed into dolphins.

title: HYMN Ζ΄. TO DIONYSIS B΄
text: But on the helmsman Dionysus had mercy and held him back and made him altogether happy, saying to him: 'Take courage, good ... you have found favour with my heart. I am loud-crying Dionysus whom Cadmus' daughter Semele bare of union with Zeus.'

spans.text: you have found favour with my heart

title: HYMN Ζ΄. TO DIONYSIS B΄
text: Hail, child of fair-faced Semele.

title: HYMN Ζ΄. TO DIONYSIS B΄
text: He who forgets you can in no wise order sweet song.

title: HYMN Η΄. TO ARES
text: Ares, exceeding in strength, chariot-rider, golden-helmed, doughty in heart, shield-bearer, Saviour of cities, harnessed in bronze, strong of arm, unwearying, mighty with the spear, O defence of Olympus, father of warlike Victory, ally of Themis, stern governor of the rebellious, leader of righteous men, sceptred King of manliness, who whirl your fiery sphere among the planets in their sevenfold courses through the aether wherein your blazing steeds ever bear you above the third firmament of heaven; hear me, helper of men, giver of dauntless youth.

title: HYMN Η΄. TO ARES
text: Shed down a kindly ray from above upon my life, and strength of war, that I may be able to drive away bitter cowardice from my head and crush down the deceitful impulses of my soul.

title: HYMN Η΄. TO ARES
text: Restrain also the keen fury of my heart which provokes me to tread the ways of blood-curdling strife.

spans.text: the keen fury of my heart

title: HYMN Η΄. TO ARES
text: Rather, O blessed one, give you me boldness to abide within the harmless laws of peace, avoiding strife and hatred and the violent fiends of death.

title: HYMN Θ΄. TO ARTEMIS Α΄
text: Muse, sing of Artemis, sister of the Far-shooter, the virgin who delights in arrows, who was fostered with Apollo.

spans.text: the virgin who delights in arrows

title: HYMN Θ΄. TO ARTEMIS Α΄
text: She waters her horses from Meles deep in reeds, and swiftly drives her all-golden chariot through Smyrna to vine-clad Claros where Apollo, god of the silver bow, sits waiting for the far-shooting goddess who delights in arrows.

title: HYMN Θ΄. TO ARTEMIS Α΄
text: And so hail to you, Artemis, in my song and to all goddesses as well.

title: HYMN Θ΄. TO ARTEMIS Α΄
text: Of you first I sing and with you I begin; now that I have begun with you, I will turn to another song.

spans.text: now that I have begun with you

title: HYMN Ι΄. TO APHRODITE Γ΄
text: Of Cytherea, born in Cyprus, I will sing.

title: HYMN Ι΄. TO APHRODITE Γ΄
text: She gives kindly gifts to men: smiles are ever on her lovely face, and lovely is the brightness that plays over it.

spans.text: She gives kindly gifts to men

title: HYMN Ι΄. TO APHRODITE Γ΄
text: Hail, goddess, queen of well-built Salamis and sea-girt Cyprus; grant me a cheerful song.

title: HYMN Ι΄. TO APHRODITE Γ΄
text: And now I will remember you and another song also.

title: HYMN ΙΑ΄. TO ATHENA Α΄
text: Of Pallas Athena, guardian of the city, I begin to sing.

title: HYMN ΙΑ΄. TO ATHENA Α΄
text: Dread is she, and with Ares she loves deeds of war, the sack of cities and the shouting and the battle.

title: HYMN ΙΑ΄. TO ATHENA Α΄
text: It is she who saves the people as they go out to war and come back.

title: HYMN ΙΑ΄. TO ATHENA Α΄
text: Hail, goddess, and give us good fortune with happiness.

title: HYMN ΙΒ΄. TO HERA
text: I sing of golden-throned Hera whom Rhea bare.

title: HYMN ΙΒ΄. TO HERA
text: Queen of the immortals is she, surpassing all in beauty: she is the sister and the wife of loud-thundering Zeus — the glorious one whom all the blessed throughout high Olympus reverence and honor even as Zeus who delights in thunder.

title: HYMN ΙΓ΄. TO DEMETER B΄
text: I begin to sing of rich-haired Demeter, awful goddess, of her and of her daughter lovely Persephone.

title: HYMN ΙΓ΄. TO DEMETER B΄
text: Hail, goddess.

title: HYMN ΙΓ΄. TO DEMETER B΄
text: Keep this city safe, and govern my song.

title: HYMN ΙΔ΄. TO THE MOTHER OF THE GODS
text: I Prithee, clear-voiced Muse, daughter of mighty Zeus, sing of the mother of all gods and men.

spans.text: mother of all gods and men

title: HYMN ΙΔ΄. TO THE MOTHER OF THE GODS
text: She is well-pleased with the sound of rattles and of timbrels, with the voice of flutes and the outcry of wolves and bright-eyed lions, with echoing hills and wooded coombes.

title: HYMN ΙΔ΄. TO THE MOTHER OF THE GODS
text: And so hail to you in my song and to all goddesses as well.

spans.text: hail to you in my song

title: HYMN ΙΕ΄. TO HERACLES
text: I will sing of Heracles, the son of Zeus and much the mightiest of men on earth.

spans.text: the mightiest of men on earth

title: HYMN ΙΕ΄. TO HERACLES
text: Alcmena bare him in Thebes, the city of lovely dances, when the dark-clouded Son of Cronos had lain with her.

title: HYMN ΙΕ΄. TO HERACLES
text: Once he used to wander over unmeasured tracts of land and sea at the bidding of King Eurystheus, and himself did many deeds of violence and endured many; but now he lives happily in the glorious home of snowy Olympus, and has neat-ankled Hebe for his wife.

spans.text: unmeasured tracts of land and sea

title: HYMN ΙΕ΄. TO HERACLES
text: Hail, lord, son of Zeus.

title: HYMN ΙΕ΄. TO HERACLES
text: Give me success and prosperity.

title: HYMN ΙϚ΄. TO ASCLEPIUS
text: I begin to sing of Asclepius, son of Apollo and healer of sicknesses.

title: HYMN ΙϚ΄. TO ASCLEPIUS
text: In the Dotian plain fair Coronis, daughter of King Phlegyas, bare him, a great joy to men, a soother of cruel pangs.

title: HYMN ΙϚ΄. TO ASCLEPIUS
text: And so hail to you, lord: in my song I make my prayer to thee.

title: HYMN ΙΖ΄. TO THE DIOSCURI Α΄
text: Sing, clear-voiced Muse, of Castor and Polydeuces, the Tyndaridae, who sprang from Olympian Zeus.

title: HYMN ΙΖ΄. TO THE DIOSCURI Α΄
text: Beneath the heights of Taygetus stately Leda bare them, when the dark-clouded Son of Cronos had privily bent her to his will.

spans.text: had privily bent her to his will

title: HYMN ΙΖ΄. TO THE DIOSCURI Α΄
text: Hail, children of Tyndareus, riders upon swift horses.

title: HYMN ΙΗ΄. TO HERMES Β΄
text: I sing of Cyllenian Hermes, the Slayer of Argus, lord of Cyllene and Arcadia rich in flocks, luck-bringing messenger of the deathless gods.

title: HYMN ΙΗ΄. TO HERMES Β΄
text: He was born of Maia, the daughter of Atlas, when she had mated with Zeus — a shy goddess she.

spans.text: when she had mated with Zeus

title: HYMN ΙΗ΄. TO HERMES Β΄
text: Ever she avoided the throng of the blessed gods and lived in a shadowy cave, and there the Son of Cronos used to lie with the rich-tressed nymph at dead of night, while white-armed Hera lay bound in sweet sleep: and neither deathless god nor mortal man knew it.

spans.text: the throng of the blessed gods
neither deathless god nor mortal man

title: HYMN ΙΗ΄. TO HERMES Β΄
text: And so hail to you, Son of Zeus and Maia; with you I have begun: now I will turn to another song.

title: HYMN ΙΗ΄. TO HERMES Β΄
text: Hail, Hermes, giver of grace, guide, and giver of good things.

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PAN
text: Muse, tell me about Pan, the dear son of Hermes, with his goat's feet and two horns — a lover of merry noise.

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PAN
text: Through wooded glades he wanders with dancing nymphs who foot it on some sheer cliff's edge, calling upon Pan, the shepherd-god, long-haired, unkempt.

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PAN
text: He has every snowy crest and the mountain peaks and rocky crests for his domain; hither and thither he goes through the close thickets, now lured by soft streams, and now he presses on amongst towering crags and climbs up to the highest peak that overlooks the flocks.

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PAN
text: Often he courses through the glistening high mountains, and often on the shouldered hills he speeds along slaying wild beasts, this keen-eyed god.

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PAN
text: Only at evening, as he returns from the chase, he sounds his note, playing sweet and low on his pipes of reed: not even she could excel him in melody —that bird who in flower-laden spring pouring forth her lament utters honey-voiced song amid the leaves.

spans.text: playing sweet and low on his pipes of reed
not even she could excel him in melody

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PAN
text: At that hour the clear-voiced nymphs are with him and move with nimble feet, singing by some spring of dark water, while Echo wails about the mountain-top, and the god on this side or on that of the choirs, or at times sidling into the midst, plies it nimbly with his feet.

spans.text: this side or on that of the choirs
plies it nimbly with his feet

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PAN
text: On his back he wears a spotted lynx-pelt, and he delights in high-pitched songs in a soft meadow where crocuses and sweet-smelling hyacinths bloom at random in the grass.

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PAN
text: They sing of the blessed gods and high Olympus and choose to tell of such an one as luck-bringing Hermes above the rest, how he is the swift messenger of all the gods, and how he came to Arcadia, the land of many springs and mother of flocks, there where his sacred place is as god of Cyllene.

spans.text: the swift messenger of all the gods

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PAN
text: For there, though a god, he used to tend curly-fleeced sheep in the service of a mortal man, because there fell on him and waxed strong melting desire to wed the rich-tressed daughter of Dryops, and there he brought about the merry marriage.

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PAN
text: And in the house she bare Hermes a dear son who from his birth was marvellous to look upon, with goat's feet and two horns —a noisy, merry-laughing child.

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PAN
text: But when the nurse saw his uncouth face and full beard, she was afraid and sprang up and fled and left the child.

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PAN
text: Then luck-bringing Hermes received him and took him in his arms: very glad in his heart was the god.

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PAN
text: And he went quickly to the abodes of the deathless gods, carrying his son wrapped in warm skins of mountain hares, and set him down beside Zeus and showed him to the rest of the gods.

spans.text: the abodes of the deathless gods
wrapped in warm skins of mountain hares

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PAN
text: Then all the immortals were glad in heart and Bacchic Dionysus in especial; and they called the boy Pan because he delighted all their hearts.

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PAN
text: And so hail to you, lord.

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PAN
text: I seek your favour with a song.

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PAN
text: And now I will remember you and another song also.

title: HYMN Κ΄. TO HEPHAESTUS
text: Sing, clear-voiced Muse, of Hephaestus famed for inventions.

title: HYMN Κ΄. TO HEPHAESTUS
text: With bright-eyed Athena he taught men glorious crafts throughout the world — men who before used to dwell in caves in the mountains like wild beasts.

spans.text: he taught men glorious crafts throughout the world

title: HYMN Κ΄. TO HEPHAESTUS
text: But now that they have learned crafts through Hephaestus the famed worker, easily they live a peaceful life in their own houses the whole year round.

title: HYMN Κ΄. TO HEPHAESTUS
text: Be gracious, Hephaestus, and grant me success and prosperity.

title: HYMN ΚΑ΄. TO APOLLO
text: Phoebus, of you even the swan sings with clear voice to the beating of his wings, as he alights upon the bank by the eddying river Peneus; and of you the sweet-tongued minstrel, holding his high-pitched lyre, always sings both first and last.

spans.text: always sings both first and last

title: HYMN ΚΑ΄. TO APOLLO
text: And so hail to you, lord.

title: HYMN ΚΑ΄. TO APOLLO
text: I seek your favor with my song.

title: HYMN ΚΒ΄. TO POSEIDON
text: I begin to sing about Poseidon, the great god, mover of the earth and fruitless sea, god of the deep who is also lord of Helicon and wide Aegae.

title: HYMN ΚΒ΄. TO POSEIDON
text: A two-fold office the gods allotted you, O Shaker of the Earth, to be a tamer of horses and a saviour of ships.

title: HYMN ΚΒ΄. TO POSEIDON
text: Hail, Poseidon, Holder of the Earth, dark-haired lord.

title: HYMN ΚΒ΄. TO POSEIDON
text: O blessed one, be kindly in heart and help those who voyage in ships.

spans.text: help those who voyage in ships

title: HYMN ΚΓ΄. TO ZEUS
text: I will sing of Zeus, chiefest among the gods and greatest, all-seeing, the lord of all, the fulfiller who whispers words of wisdom to Themis as she sits leaning towards him.

title: HYMN ΚΓ΄. TO ZEUS
text: Be gracious, all-seeing Son of Cronos, most excellent and great.

title: HYMN ΚΔ΄. TO HESTIA Α΄
text: Hestia, you who tend the holy house of the lord Apollo, the Far-shooter at goodly Pytho, with soft oil dripping ever from your locks, come now into this house, come, having one mind with Zeus the all-wise — draw near, and withal bestow grace upon my song.

title: HYMN ΚΕ΄. TO THE MUSES AND APOLLO
text: I will begin with the Muses and Apollo and Zeus.

title: HYMN ΚΕ΄. TO THE MUSES AND APOLLO
text: For it is through the Muses and Apollo that there are singers upon the earth and players upon the lyre; but kings are from Zeus.

title: HYMN ΚΕ΄. TO THE MUSES AND APOLLO
text: Happy is he whom the Muses love: sweet flows speech from his lips.

title: HYMN ΚΕ΄. TO THE MUSES AND APOLLO
text: Hail, children of Zeus.

title: HYMN ΚΕ΄. TO THE MUSES AND APOLLO
text: Give honor to my song.

title: HYMN ΚΕ΄. TO THE MUSES AND APOLLO
text: And now I will remember you and another song also.

title: HYMN ΚϚ΄. TO DIONYSUS Γ΄
text: I begin to sing of ivy-crowned Dionysus, the loud-crying god, splendid son of Zeus and glorious Semele.

title: HYMN ΚϚ΄. TO DIONYSUS Γ΄
text: The rich-haired Nymphs received him in their bosoms from the lord his father and fostered and nurtured him carefully in the dells of Nysa, where by the will of his father he grew up in a sweet-smelling cave, being reckoned among the immortals.

title: HYMN ΚϚ΄. TO DIONYSUS Γ΄
text: But when the goddesses had brought him up, a god oft hymned, then began he to wander continually through the woody coombes, thickly wreathed with ivy and laurel.

spans.text: thickly wreathed with ivy and laurel

title: HYMN ΚϚ΄. TO DIONYSUS Γ΄
text: And the Nymphs followed in his train with him for their leader; and the boundless forest was filled with their outcry.

title: HYMN ΚϚ΄. TO DIONYSUS Γ΄
text: And so hail to you, Dionysus, god of abundant clusters.

title: HYMN ΚϚ΄. TO DIONYSUS Γ΄
text: Grant that we may come again rejoicing to this season, and from that season onwards for many a year.

spans.text: Grant that we may come again rejoicing to this season
from that season onwards for many a year

title: HYMN ΚΖ΄. TO ARTEMIS Β΄
text: I sing of Artemis, whose shafts are of gold, who cheers on the hounds, the pure maiden, shooter of stags, who delights in archery, own sister to Apollo with the golden sword.

title: HYMN ΚΖ΄. TO ARTEMIS Β΄
text: Over the shadowy hills and windy peaks she draws her golden bow, rejoicing in the chase, and sends out grievous shafts.

title: HYMN ΚΖ΄. TO ARTEMIS Β΄
text: The tops of the high mountains tremble and the tangled wood echoes awesomely with the outcry of beasts: earth quakes and the sea also where fishes shoal.

spans.text: the tops of the high mountains

title: HYMN ΚΖ΄. TO ARTEMIS Β΄
text: But the goddess with a bold heart turns every way destroying the race of wild beasts: and when she is satisfied and has cheered her heart, this huntress who delights in arrows slackens her supple bow and goes to the great house of her dear brother Phoebus Apollo, to the rich land of Delphi, there to order the lovely dance of the Muses and Graces.

spans.text: destroying the race of wild beasts
to the rich land of Delphi
the lovely dance of the Muses and Graces

title: HYMN ΚΖ΄. TO ARTEMIS Β΄
text: There she hangs up her curved bow and her arrows, and heads and leads the dances, gracefully arrayed, while all they utter their heavenly voice, singing how neat-ankled Leto bare children supreme among the immortals both in thought and in deed.

title: HYMN ΚΖ΄. TO ARTEMIS Β΄
text: Hail to you, children of Zeus and rich-haired Leto.

title: HYMN ΚΖ΄. TO ARTEMIS Β΄
text: And now I will remember you and another song also.

title: HYMN ΚΗ΄. TO ATHENA Β΄
text: I begin to sing of Pallas Athena, the glorious goddess, bright-eyed, inventive, unbending of heart, pure virgin, saviour of cities, courageous, Tritogeneia.

title: HYMN ΚΗ΄. TO ATHENA Β΄
text: Wise Zeus himself bare her from his awful head, arrayed in warlike arms of flashing gold, and awe seized all the gods as they gazed.

spans.text: arrayed in warlike arms of flashing gold

title: HYMN ΚΗ΄. TO ATHENA Β΄
text: But Athena sprang quickly from the immortal head and stood before Zeus who holds the aegis, shaking a sharp spear: great Olympus began to reel horribly at the might of the bright-eyed goddess, and earth round about cried fearfully, and the sea was moved and tossed with dark waves, while foam burst forth suddenly: the bright Son of Hyperion stopped his swift-footed horses a long while, until the maiden Pallas Athena had stripped the heavenly armour from her immortal shoulders.

title: HYMN ΚΗ΄. TO ATHENA Β΄
text: And wise Zeus was glad.

title: HYMN ΚΗ΄. TO ATHENA Β΄
text: And so hail to you, daughter of Zeus who holds the aegis.

title: HYMN ΚΗ΄. TO ATHENA Β΄
text: Now I will remember you and another song as well.

title: HYMN ΚΘ΄. TO HESTIA Β΄
text: Hestia, in the high dwellings of all, both deathless gods and men who walk on earth, you have gained an everlasting abode and highest honor: glorious is your portion and your right.

title: HYMN ΚΘ΄. TO HESTIA Β΄
text: For without you mortals hold no banquet — where one does not duly pour sweet wine in offering to Hestia both first and last.

title: HYMN ΚΘ΄. TO HESTIA Β΄
text: And you, Slayer of Argus, Son of Zeus and Maia, messenger of the blessed gods, bearer of the golden rod, giver of good, be favorable and help us, you and Hestia, the worshipful and dear.

title: HYMN ΚΘ΄. TO HESTIA Β΄
text: Come and dwell in this glorious house in friendship together; for you two, well knowing the noble actions of men, aid on their wisdom and their strength.

title: HYMN ΚΘ΄. TO HESTIA Β΄
text: Hail, Daughter of Cronos, and you also, Hermes, bearer of the golden rod.

title: HYMN ΚΘ΄. TO HESTIA Β΄
text: Now I will remember you and another song also.

title: HYMN Λ΄. TO EARTH
text: I will sing of well-founded Earth, mother of all, eldest of all beings.

title: HYMN Λ΄. TO EARTH
text: She feeds all creatures that are in the world, all that go upon the goodly land, and all that are in the paths of the seas, and all that fly: all these are fed of her store.

spans.text: She feeds all creatures that are in the world
all that go upon the goodly land
all that are in the paths of the seas

title: HYMN Λ΄. TO EARTH
text: Through you, O queen, men are blessed in their children and blessed in their harvests, and to you it belongs to give means of life to mortal men and to take it away.

title: HYMN Λ΄. TO EARTH
text: Happy is the man whom you delight to honor.

title: HYMN Λ΄. TO EARTH
text: He has all things abundantly: his fruitful land is laden with corn, his pastures are covered with cattle, and his house is filled with good things.

title: HYMN Λ΄. TO EARTH
text: Such men rule orderly in their cities of fair women: great riches and wealth follow them: their sons exult with ever-fresh delight, and their daughters in flower-laden bands play and skip merrily over the soft flowers of the field.

title: HYMN Λ΄. TO EARTH
text: Thus is it with those whom you honor O holy goddess, bountiful spirit.

title: HYMN Λ΄. TO EARTH
text: Hail, Mother of the gods, wife of starry Heaven; freely bestow upon me for this my song substance that cheers the heart.

title: HYMN Λ΄. TO EARTH
text: And now I will remember you and another song also.

title: HYMN ΛΑ΄. TO HELIOS
text: And now, O Muse Calliope, daughter of Zeus, begin to sing of glowing Helios whom mild-eyed Euryphaessa, the far-shining one, bare to the Son of Earth and starry Heaven.

title: HYMN ΛΑ΄. TO HELIOS
text: For Hyperion wedded glorious Euryphaessa, his own sister, who bare him lovely children, rosy-armed Eos and rich-tressed Selene and tireless Helios who is like the deathless gods.

title: HYMN ΛΑ΄. TO HELIOS
text: As he rides in his chariot, he shines upon men and deathless gods, and piercingly he gazes with his eyes from his golden helmet.

spans.text: shines upon men and deathless gods
piercingly he gazes with his eyes

title: HYMN ΛΑ΄. TO HELIOS
text: Bright rays beam dazzlingly from him, and his bright locks streaming from the temples of his head gracefully enclose his far-seen face: a rich, fine-spun garment glows upon his body and flutters in the wind: and stallions carry him.

spans.text: streaming from the temples of his head

title: HYMN ΛΑ΄. TO HELIOS
text: Then, when he has stayed his golden-yoked chariot and horses, he rests there upon the highest point of heaven, until he marvelously drives them down again through heaven to Ocean.

title: HYMN ΛΑ΄. TO HELIOS
text: Hail to you, lord.

title: HYMN ΛΑ΄. TO HELIOS
text: Freely bestow on me substance that cheers the heart.

title: HYMN ΛΑ΄. TO HELIOS
text: And now that I have begun with you, I will celebrate the race of mortal men half-divine whose deeds the Muses have showed to mankind.

spans.text: the race of mortal men half-divine

title: HYMN ΛΒ΄. TO SELENE
text: And next, sweet voiced Muses, daughters of Zeus, well-skilled in song, tell of the long-winged Moon.

title: HYMN ΛΒ΄. TO SELENE
text: From her immortal head a radiance is shown from heaven and embraces earth; and great is the beauty that ariseth from her shining light.

title: HYMN ΛΒ΄. TO SELENE
text: The air, unlit before, glows with the light of her golden crown, and her rays beam clear, whensoever bright Selene having bathed her lovely body in the waters of Ocean, and donned her far-gleaming raiment, and yoked her strong-necked, shining team, drives on her long-maned horses at full speed, at eventime in the mid-month: then her great orbit is full and then her beams shine brightest as she increases.

spans.text: the light of her golden crown

title: HYMN ΛΒ΄. TO SELENE
text: So she is a sure token and a sign to mortal men.

title: HYMN ΛΒ΄. TO SELENE
text: Once the Son of Cronos was joined with her in love; and she conceived and bare a daughter Pandia, exceeding lovely amongst the deathless gods.

spans.text: she conceived and bare a daughter Pandia

title: HYMN ΛΒ΄. TO SELENE
text: Hail, white-armed goddess, bright Selene, mild, bright-tressed queen.

title: HYMN ΛΒ΄. TO SELENE
text: And now I will leave you and sing the glories of men half-divine, whose deeds minstrels, the servants of the Muses, celebrate with lovely lips.

spans.text: sing the glories of men half-divine

title: HYMN ΛΓ΄. TO THE DIOSCURI Β΄
text: Bright-eyed Muses, tell of the Tyndaridae, the Sons of Zeus, glorious children of neat-ankled Leda, Castor the tamer of horses, and blameless Polydeuces.

title: HYMN ΛΓ΄. TO THE DIOSCURI Β΄
text: When Leda had lain with the dark-clouded Son of Cronos, she bare them beneath the peak of the great hill Taygetus — children who are deliverers of men on earth and of swift-going ships when stormy gales rage over the ruthless sea.

spans.text: beneath the peak of the great hill Taygetus
children who are deliverers of men on earth

title: HYMN ΛΓ΄. TO THE DIOSCURI Β΄
text: Then the shipmen call upon the sons of great Zeus with vows of white lambs, going to the forepart of the prow; but the strong wind and the waves of the sea lay the ship under water, until suddenly these two are seen darting through the air on tawny wings.

title: HYMN ΛΓ΄. TO THE DIOSCURI Β΄
text: Forthwith they allay the blasts of the cruel winds and still the waves upon the surface of the white sea: fair signs are they and deliverance from toil.

spans.text: they allay the blasts of the cruel winds
the waves upon the surface of the white sea

title: HYMN ΛΓ΄. TO THE DIOSCURI Β΄
text: And when the shipmen see them they are glad and have rest from their pain and labour.

spans.text: have rest from their pain and labour

title: HYMN ΛΓ΄. TO THE DIOSCURI Β΄
text: Hail, Tyndaridae, riders upon swift horses.

title: HYMN ΛΓ΄. TO THE DIOSCURI Β΄
text: Now I will remember you and another song also.

title: HYMN Α΄. ORPHEUS TO MOUSAIOS
text: Learn now, Mousaios, a mystical and most holy rite, a prayer which surely excels all others.

title: HYMN Α΄. ORPHEUS TO MOUSAIOS
text: Kind Zeus and Earth, heavenly and pure flames of Sun, sacred light of Moon, and of all the Stars; Poseidon, too, dark-maned holder of the earth, pure Persephone, Demeter of the splendid fruit, Artemis, arrow-pouring maiden, kindly Phoibos, dwelling on the sacred ground of Delphoi, and Dionysos, the dancer, whose honors among the blessed gods are the highest; strong-spirited Ares, holy and mighty Hephaistos, then the goddess foam-born, to whose lot fell sublime gifts, and you, divinity excellent, king of the underworld.

spans.text: heavenly and pure flames of Sun
dwelling on the sacred ground of Delphoi
whose honors among the blessed gods are the highest
to whose lot fell sublime gifts

title: HYMN Α΄. ORPHEUS TO MOUSAIOS
text: I call on Hebe, and Eileithyia, and the noble ardor of Herakles, I call upon the great blessings of Justice and Piety, I call upon the glorious Nymphs and upon Pan the greatest, I call upon Hera, buxom wife of aegis-bearing Zeus.

title: HYMN Α΄. ORPHEUS TO MOUSAIOS
text: And I call upon lovely Mnemosyne, I call upon the holy Muses, all nine, and then I call upon the Graces, the Seasons, and the Year, upon fair-tressed Leto, and upon divine and revered Dione.

title: HYMN Α΄. ORPHEUS TO MOUSAIOS
text: I invoke the armed Kouretes, the Korybantes, and the Kabeiroi, the great Saviors, Zeus' ageless scions, I invoke the Idaian gods, and Hermes, messenger and herald.

title: HYMN Α΄. ORPHEUS TO MOUSAIOS
text: Of those in the sky, I invoke Themis, diviner of men, and then I invoke Night, oldest of all, and I do invoke light-bringing Day.

title: HYMN Α΄. ORPHEUS TO MOUSAIOS
text: Faith, Dike, I invoke, I invoke blameless Thesmodoteira, and Rhea, and Kronos, and dark-veiled Tethys, the great Okeanos, and all of his daughters.

title: HYMN Α΄. ORPHEUS TO MOUSAIOS
text: I invoke the might preeminent of Atlas and Aion, of Time the ever-flowing, and of the splendid water of the Styx.

spans.text: the splendid water of the Styx

title: HYMN Α΄. ORPHEUS TO MOUSAIOS
text: I call on all these gentle gods, and I call on Pronoia, and on the holy Daimon, I also call on Daimon baneful to mortals, then I invoke divinities dwelling in the sky, in the air, in the water, on earth, under the earth, and in the fiery element.

title: HYMN Α΄. ORPHEUS TO MOUSAIOS
text: Ino, Leukothea, Palaimon, giver of bliss, sweet-speaking Nike, queenly Adrasteia, I call upon the great king Asklepios, who grants soothing, upon the battle-stirring maiden Pallas, and upon all the winds, I call upon Thunder, and upon the parts of the four-pillared cosmos.

spans.text: the parts of the four-pillared cosmos

title: HYMN Α΄. ORPHEUS TO MOUSAIOS
text: I invoke the Mother of the immortals, Attis and Men, I invoke the goddess Ourania, and the immortal and holy Adonis, Beginning and End, too, which to all is most important, and I ask them to come in a spirit of joyous mercy to this holy rite, to this reverent libation.

title: HYMN Β΄. TO HEKATE
text: Lovely Hekate of the roads and of the crossroads I invoke.

title: HYMN Β΄. TO HEKATE
text: In heaven, on earth, then in the sea, saffron-cloaked, tomb spirit reveling in the souls of the dead, daughter of Perses, haunting deserted places, delighting in deer, nocturnal, dog-loving, monstrous queen, devouring wild beasts, ungirt and repulsive.

title: HYMN Β΄. TO HEKATE
text: Herder of bulls, queen and mistress of the whole world, leader, nymph, mountain-roaming nurturer of youths, maiden, I beseech you to come to these holy rites, ever with joyous heart, ever favoring the oxherd.

spans.text: queen and mistress of the whole world
I beseech you to come to these holy rites

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO PROTHYRAIA
text: Hear me, O revered goddess, O many-named divinity, O sight sweet to women in labor, you offer them aid in travail.

spans.text: sight sweet to women in labor
you offer them aid in travail

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO PROTHYRAIA
text: You save women, and you alone love children, O kindly goddess of swift birth, ever helpful to young women, O Prothyraia.

spans.text: O kindly goddess of swift birth

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO PROTHYRAIA
text: You hold the keys, you are accessible to all, O mistress, gracious and fond of nurture, you have power in every house, and you delight in festivities.

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO PROTHYRAIA
text: You loosen girdles, and though invisible you are seen in every deed, you share pain, you rejoice in every birth, O Eileithyia, you free from pain those in terrible distress.

spans.text: though invisible you are seen in every deed
you free from pain those in terrible distress

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO PROTHYRAIA
text: Upon you alone pregnant women call, O comforter of souls, and in you alone there is relief from pains of labor.

title: HYMN Γ΄. TO PROTHYRAIA
text: Artemis, Eileithyia, reverend Prothyraia, hear, O blessed one, help me and grant offspring; save me, savior of all, for it is in your nature to do so.

spans.text: in your nature to do so

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO NIGHT
text: I shall sing of Night, mother of gods and men; we call Night Kypris, she gave birth to all.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO NIGHT
text: Hear, O blessed goddess, jet-black and starlit, for you delight in the quiet and slumber-filled serenity.

spans.text: you delight in the quiet and slumber-filled serenity

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO NIGHT
text: Cheerful and delightful, lover of the nightlong revel, mother of dreams, you free us from cares, you offer us welcome respite from toil.

spans.text: you offer us welcome respite from toil

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO NIGHT
text: Giver of sleep, beloved of all, you gleam in the darkness as you drive your steeds.

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO NIGHT
text: Ever incomplete, terrestrial, and then again celestial, you circle around in pursuit of sprightly phantoms, you force light into the nether world, and then again you flee into Hades, for dreadful Necessity governs all things.

spans.text: you circle around in pursuit of sprightly phantoms
you force light into the nether world

title: HYMN Δ΄. TO NIGHT
text: But now, O blessed one, beatific, desired by all, I call on you to grant a kind ear to my voice of supplication, and to come, benevolent, to disperse fears that glisten in the night.

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO SKY
text: Sky, father of all, eternal cosmic element, primeval beginning of all, end of all, lord of the universe, moving about the earth like a sphere.

spans.text: moving about the earth like a sphere

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO SKY
text: You are home of the blessed gods, your motion is a roaring whirl, you envelop all, celestial and terrestrial guard.

spans.text: your motion is a roaring whirl

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO SKY
text: Physis' invincible drive lies in your breast.

title: HYMN Ε΄. TO SKY
text: Dark-blue, indomitable, shimmering, variform, all-seeing father of Kronos, blessed and most sublime divinity, hearken, bring a life of holiness to the new initiates.

title: HYMN Ϛ΄. TO ETHER
text: Yours are Zeus' lofty dwelling, endless power, too; of the stars, of the sun, and of the moon you claim a share.

title: HYMN Ϛ΄. TO ETHER
text: O tamer of all, O fire-breather, O life's spark for every creature, sublime Ether, best cosmic element, radiant, luminous, starlit offspring, I call upon you and I beseech you to be temperate and clear.

spans.text: I beseech you to be temperate and clear

title: HYMN Ζ΄. TO PROTOGONOS
text: Upon two-natured Protogonos, great and ether-tossed, I call; born of the egg, delighting in his golden wings, the begetter of blessed gods and mortal men; he bellows like a bull.

spans.text: begetter of blessed gods and mortal men

title: HYMN Ζ΄. TO PROTOGONOS
text: Erikepaios, seed unforgettable, attended by many rites, ineffable, hidden, brilliant scion, forever in whirring motion, you scattered the dark mist, the mist that lay before your eyes.

spans.text: the mist that lay before your eyes

title: HYMN Ζ΄. TO PROTOGONOS
