text: Flapping your wings, you whirled about throughout this world, you brought pure light.

spans.text: you whirled about throughout this world

title: HYMN Ζ΄. TO PROTOGONOS
text: For this I call you Phanes, yes, I call you Lord Priapos, I call you bright-eyed Antauges.

title: HYMN Ζ΄. TO PROTOGONOS
text: O blessed one of the many counsels and of the many seeds, come joyfully to the celebrants of this holy rite, of this very intricate rite.

spans.text: blessed one of the many counsels

title: HYMN Η΄. TO THE STARS
text: I call forth the sacred light of the heavenly Stars, with devotional prayers I summon the holy daimones.

title: HYMN Η΄. TO THE STARS
text: Heavenly Stars, dear children of black Night, round your thrones you move in circles, you spin in circular ways, O brilliant and fiery begetters of all, you do reveal fate, everyone's fate, you determine the divine path for mortals.

spans.text: brilliant and fiery begetters of all
determine the divine path for mortals

title: HYMN Η΄. TO THE STARS
text: Wandering in midair, you gaze upon the seven luminous orbits.

title: HYMN Η΄. TO THE STARS
text: In heaven and on earth, ever indestructible on your blazing trail, you shine upon the darkness of the cloak night wears.

title: HYMN Η΄. TO THE STARS
text: Coruscating and gleaming, kingly and nocturnal, visit the learned contests of this sacred rite, finish a noble race for works of renown.

title: HYMN Θ΄. TO THE SUN
text: Hear me, O blessed one, eternal eye that sees all, Titan radiant as gold, Hyperion, celestial light, self-born, untiring, sweet sight to living creatures.

title: HYMN Θ΄. TO THE SUN
text: On the right you beget dawn, on the left you beget night, you temper the seasons as you ride your dancing horses, you rush, you rush very swiftly, O fiery and bright-faced charioteer, you press on your course in endless whirl.

title: HYMN Θ΄. TO THE SUN
text: Harsh to the impious, you teach good to the pious as you hold the golden lyre, the harmony of cosmic motion, as you command noble deeds, as you nurture the seasons.

spans.text: you teach good to the pious

title: HYMN Θ΄. TO THE SUN
text: Piping lord of the world, fiery circle of motion, life-bringing, coruscating, life-giving, fruit-bearing, Paian, eternal and pure father of time, O immortal Zeus, you are the clear, you are the brilliant, you are the all-encompassing cosmic eye, both when you set and when you shine your lovely and radiant light.

spans.text: eternal and pure father of time
when you shine your lovely and radiant light

title: HYMN Θ΄. TO THE SUN
text: A paragon of justice, O water-loving lord of the cosmos, you guard pledges and ever the highest, you do help all.

spans.text: O water-loving lord of the cosmos

title: HYMN Θ΄. TO THE SUN
text: Eye of justice and light of life, O charioteer, your screaming whip drives the four-horse chariot on.

title: HYMN Θ΄. TO THE SUN
text: Hear my words and show life's sweetness to the initiates.

title: HYMN Ι΄. TO SELENE
text: Hear me, O divine queen, O light-bringing and splendid Selene, O bull-horned Moon, crossing the air as you race with night.

title: HYMN Ι΄. TO SELENE
text: Nocturnal, torch-bearing, maiden of beautiful stars, O Moon, waxing and waning, feminine and masculine, luminous, lover of horses, mother of time, bearer of fruit, amber-colored, moody, shining in the night, all-seeing and vigilant, surrounded by beautiful stars, you delight in the quiet and in the richness of the night, you grant fulfillment and favor, as, like a jewel, you shine in the night.

spans.text: you delight in the quiet and in the richness of the night

title: HYMN Ι΄. TO SELENE
text: Long-cloaked marshal of the stars, wise maiden whose motion is circular, come, O blessed and gentle lady, lady of the stars, through your own light shine and save, O maiden, your new initiates.

spans.text: wise maiden whose motion is circular

title: HYMN ΙΑ΄. TO PHYSIS
text: O Physis, resourceful mother of all, industrious and rich divinity, oldest of all, queen, all-taming and indomitable, O lustrous ruler, ever-honored mistress of all, highest goddess, imperishable, first-born, fabled glorifier of men, nocturnal, radiant with constellations, light-bringing, irrepressible, you move swiftly, your steps are noiseless, O pure marshal of the gods, O end that has no end.

title: HYMN ΙΑ΄. TO PHYSIS
text: All partake of you, you alone partake of no one.

spans.text: you alone partake of no one

title: HYMN ΙΑ΄. TO PHYSIS
text: Self-fathered, hence fatherless, virtue itself, joyous, great, you are accessible, O nurse of flowers, you lovingly mingle and twine, you lead and rule, you bring life and nourishment to all.

title: HYMN ΙΑ΄. TO PHYSIS
text: Self-sufficient, many-named persuasion of the Graces, Dike herself, queen of heaven, queen of the earth and of the sea, bitter to the vulgar, sweet to those who obey you, wise in all, giver of all, nurturing queen of all, abundant nourishment is yours as you dissolve whatever ripens, father and mother of all, nurturer and nurse, giver of swift birth, O blessed one, giver of wealth of seeds and of the fever of seasons.

spans.text: sweet to those who obey you

title: HYMN ΙΑ΄. TO PHYSIS
text: A rich and mighty divinity, you give shape and form to all things.

spans.text: you give shape and form to all things

title: HYMN ΙΑ΄. TO PHYSIS
text: Eternal, setting all in motion, skilled and discreet, you are ever turning the swift stream into an unceasing eddy, flowing in all things, circular and ever changing form, fair-throned and precious, you alone accomplish your designs, mighty mistress of booming thunder, you rule over those who hold the scepter, O loud-roaring divinity, fearless, all-taming, destined fate, fire-breathing, you are life everlasting, you are immortal providence.

spans.text: ever turning the swift stream into an unceasing eddy
you rule over those who hold the scepter

title: HYMN ΙΑ΄. TO PHYSIS
text: You are all things to all, because you alone do.

spans.text: You are all things to all

title: HYMN ΙΑ΄. TO PHYSIS
text: You are the all, you alone do, you bring peace and health, you bring growth to all.

title: HYMN ΙΒ΄. TO PAN
text: I call upon Pan, the pastoral god, I call upon the universe, upon the sky, the sea, and the land, queen of all, I also call upon immortal fire; all these are Pan's realm.

title: HYMN ΙΒ΄. TO PAN
text: Come, O blessed and frolicsome one, O restless companion of the Seasons!

title: HYMN ΙΒ΄. TO PAN
text: Goat-limbed, reveling, lover of frenzy, star-haunting, weaver of playful song, song of cosmic harmony, you induce fantasies of dread into the minds of mortals, you delight in gushing springs, surrounded by goatherds and oxherds, you dance with the nymphs, you sharp-eyed hunter, lover of Echo.

spans.text: you induce fantasies of dread into the minds of mortals

title: HYMN ΙΒ΄. TO PAN
text: Present in all growth, begetter of all, many-named divinity, light-bringing lord of the cosmos, fructifying Paian, cave-loving and wrathful, veritable Zeus with horns, the earth's endless plain is supported by you, and the deep-flowing water of the weariless sea yields to you, Okeanos who girds the earth with his eddying stream gives way to you, and so does the air we breathe, the air that kindles all life, and above us the sublime eye of weightless fire; at your behest all these are kept wide apart.

spans.text: deep-flowing water of the weariless sea
Okeanos who girds the earth with his eddying stream
the air that kindles all life
the sublime eye of weightless fire

title: HYMN ΙΒ΄. TO PAN
text: Your providence alters the natures of all, on the boundless earth you offer nourishment to mankind.

title: HYMN ΙΒ΄. TO PAN
text: Come, frenzy-loving, spirit-possessed, come to these sacred libations, come and bring my life to a good end.

spans.text: bring my life to a good end

title: HYMN ΙΒ΄. TO PAN
text: Send your madness, O Pan, to the ends of the earth.

title: HYMN ΙΓ΄. TO HERAKLES
text: Herakles, stout-hearted and mighty, powerful Titan, strong-handed, indomitable, doer of valiant deeds, shape-shifter, O gentle and endless father of time, ineffable, lord of all, many pray to you, all-conquering and mighty archer and seer, omnivorous begetter of all, peak of all, helper to all, for the sake of men you subdued and tamed savage races.

spans.text: gentle and endless father of time
for the sake of men you subdued and tamed savage races

title: HYMN ΙΓ΄. TO HERAKLES
text: Peace was your desire; she brings dazzling honors and nurtures youths.

title: HYMN ΙΓ΄. TO HERAKLES
text: Self-grown, weariless, bravest child of the earth, O illustrious Paion, your primordial scales gleam.

title: HYMN ΙΓ΄. TO HERAKLES
text: Round your head dawn and dark night cling, and your twelve deeds of valor stretch from east to west.

title: HYMN ΙΓ΄. TO HERAKLES
text: Immortal, world-wise, boundless and irrepressible, come, O blessed one, come, O blessed one, bringing all charms against disease, with club in hand drive evil bane away, with your poisonous darts do ward off cruel death.

title: HYMN ΙΔ΄. TO KRONOS
text: Everlasting father of blessed gods and men, resourceful, pure and mighty, O powerful Titan, you consume all things and replenish them, too.

spans.text: Everlasting father of blessed gods and men
you consume all things and replenish them

title: HYMN ΙΔ΄. TO KRONOS
text: Unbreakable is the hold you have on the boundless cosmos, O Kronos, begetter of time, Kronos of the shifting stories, child of Earth, child of starry Sky.

spans.text: the hold you have on the boundless cosmos

title: HYMN ΙΔ΄. TO KRONOS
text: In you there is birth and decline, O revered and prudent lord of Rhea, you are the progenitor, you dwell in every part of the world.

spans.text: O revered and prudent lord of Rhea
you dwell in every part of the world

title: HYMN ΙΔ΄. TO KRONOS
text: I am a suppliant, hear my voice, O wily and brave one, and to a good life bring a blameless end.

title: HYMN ΙΕ΄. TO RHEA
text: Mighty Rhea, daughter of many-faced Protogonos, your sacred chariot is drawn by bull-slayers, you dance to the sound of drums and cymbals, O frenzy-loving maiden, O mother of Zeus, aegis-bearing lord of Olympos.

spans.text: you dance to the sound of drums and cymbals

title: HYMN ΙΕ΄. TO RHEA
text: Illustrious and honored, Kronos' blessed consort, you delight in the mountains and in the horrid shrieks of mortals.

title: HYMN ΙΕ΄. TO RHEA
text: Strong-spirited Rhea, queen of queens, lover of the battle din, liar, savior, redeemer, first by birth, mother of gods and of mortals, from you come the earth, and the wide sky above, and the sea and the winds.

spans.text: mother of gods and of mortals

title: HYMN ΙΕ΄. TO RHEA
text: Ethereal and restless, come, O blessed goddess, O gentle-minded savior, come, bring peace and wealth and abundance of possessions, and do send death and the filth of pollution to the ends of the earth.

title: HYMN ΙϚ΄. TO ZEUS
text: Much-honored Zeus, great god, indestructible Zeus, we lay before you in prayer redeeming testimony.

spans.text: we lay before you in prayer redeeming testimony

title: HYMN ΙϚ΄. TO ZEUS
text: O king, you have brought to light divine works, earth, goddess and mother, the hills swept by the shrill winds, the sea and the host of the stars, marshaled by the sky.

title: HYMN ΙϚ΄. TO ZEUS
text: Kronian Zeus, strong-spirited god, the thunderbolt is your scepter, father of all, beginning and end of all, earth-shaker, increaser and purifier, all-shaker, god of thunder and lightning, Zeus the sower.

title: HYMN ΙϚ΄. TO ZEUS
text: Hear me, god of many faces, grant me unblemished health, please grant me divine peace and riches, please grant me glory without blame.

title: HYMN ΙΖ΄. TO HERA
text: You lodge yourself in dark hollows, and your form is airy, O Hera, blessed queen of all, consort of Zeus.

title: HYMN ΙΖ΄. TO HERA
text: The soft breezes you send to mortals nourish the soul, O mother of rains, mother of the winds, you give birth to all.

title: HYMN ΙΖ΄. TO HERA
text: Life does not exist without you, growth does not exist without you.

title: HYMN ΙΖ΄. TO HERA
text: You are in everything, even in the air we venerate, you are queen, and you are mistress.

title: HYMN ΙΖ΄. TO HERA
text: You toss and turn when the rushing wind tosses and turns.

title: HYMN ΙΖ΄. TO HERA
text: O blessed goddess, many-named queen of all, may you come with kindness on your joyous face.

spans.text: may you come with kindness on your joyous face

title: HYMN ΙΗ΄. TO POSEIDON
text: Hearken, dark-maned Poseidon, holder of the earth, horse god, you hold the bronze trident in your hand, you dwell in the foundations of the full-bosomed sea.

title: HYMN ΙΗ΄. TO POSEIDON
text: Shaker of the earth, deep-roaring ruler of the waters, the waves are your blossoms, O gracious one, as you urge horses and chariots on, rushing on the sea, splashing through the rippling brine.

title: HYMN ΙΗ΄. TO POSEIDON
text: The unfathomable sea fell to your lot, the third portion.

title: HYMN ΙΗ΄. TO POSEIDON
text: Waves and their wild dwellers please you, O spirit of the deep.

title: HYMN ΙΗ΄. TO POSEIDON
text: May you save the foundations of the earth and ships moving at full tilt, bringing peace, health, and blameless prosperity.

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PLOUTON
text: You dwell below the earth, O strong-spirited one, a meadow in Tartaros, thick-shaded and dark.

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PLOUTON
text: Sceptered Chthonic Zeus, please accept this sacrifice, O Plouton, holder of the keys to the whole earth.

spans.text: holder of the keys to the whole earth

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PLOUTON
text: To mankind you give the wealth of the year's fruits, yours is the third portion, earth, queen of all, seat of the gods, mighty lap of mortals.

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PLOUTON
text: Your throne rests on a dark realm, the realm of distant, of untiring, of windless, and of impassive Hades; it does rest on gloomy Acheron, the river who girds the roots of the earth.

spans.text: who girds the roots of the earth

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PLOUTON
text: All-receiver, master of death, master of mortals, host of many, Euboulos, you once took as your bride pure Demeter's daughter: you tore her away from the meadow, and through the sea you carried her to an Attic cave upon your steeds— it was the district of Eleusis, it was the district of Eleusis, where the gates to Hades are.

spans.text: tore her away from the meadow

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PLOUTON
text: You alone were born to judge deeds obscure and conspicuous.

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PLOUTON
text: Holiest and illustrious ruler of all, frenzied god, you delight in the respect and in the reverence of your worshippers.

spans.text: Holiest and illustrious ruler of all
you delight in the respect and in the reverence of your worshippers

title: HYMN ΙΘ΄. TO PLOUTON
text: I summon you, come with favor, come with joy to the initiates.

title: HYMN Κ΄. TO ZEUS THE THUNDERBOLT
text: Father Zeus, sublime is the course of the blazing cosmos you drive on, ethereal and lofty the flash of your lightning as you shake the seat of the gods with a god's thunderbolt.

spans.text: the course of the blazing cosmos
you shake the seat of the gods

title: HYMN Κ΄. TO ZEUS THE THUNDERBOLT
text: The fire of your lightning emblazons the rain clouds, you bring storms and hurricanes, you bring mighty gales, you hurl roaring thunder, a shower of arrows.

title: HYMN Κ΄. TO ZEUS THE THUNDERBOLT
text: Horrific might and strength sets all aflame, dreadful missile makes hearts pound and hair bristle.

title: HYMN Κ΄. TO ZEUS THE THUNDERBOLT
text: Holy and invincible, it comes with a sudden crash, an endless spiral of noise, omnivorous in its drive, unbreakable and threatening, ineluctable, too, the gale's sharp and smoke-filled shafts swoop down with a flash dreaded by land and sea.

spans.text: the gale's sharp and smoke-filled shafts
a flash dreaded by land and sea

title: HYMN Κ΄. TO ZEUS THE THUNDERBOLT
text: Wild beasts cringe when they hear the noise, faces reflect the brilliance of thunder roaring in the celestial hollows.

title: HYMN Κ΄. TO ZEUS THE THUNDERBOLT
text: You tear the robe that cloaks heaven, you hurl the fiery thunderbolt.

title: HYMN Κ΄. TO ZEUS THE THUNDERBOLT
text: O blessed one..., the anger of the sea waves, the anger of the mountain peaks— we all know your power.

spans.text: the anger of the sea waves
the anger of the mountain peaks

title: HYMN Κ΄. TO ZEUS THE THUNDERBOLT
text: Enjoy this libation and give all things pleasing to the heart: a life of prosperity, queenly health, divine peace that nurtures youths, crowned with honors, a life ever blooming with cheerful thoughts.

spans.text: all things pleasing to the heart
a life ever blooming with cheerful thoughts

title: HYMN ΚΑ΄. TO ASTRAPAIOS ZEUS
text: I call upon great and pure, upon resounding and illustrious, upon ethereal and blazing Zeus, whose racing fire shines through the air.

title: HYMN ΚΑ΄. TO ASTRAPAIOS ZEUS
text: Your light flashes through the clouds with an ear-splitting clap.

title: HYMN ΚΑ΄. TO ASTRAPAIOS ZEUS
text: O horrid, O wrathful and pure, O invincible god, lord of lightning, I call upon you, O begetter of all, O great king, to be kind and to bring a sweet end to my life.

spans.text: to bring a sweet end to my life

title: HYMN ΚΒ΄. TO THE CLOUDS
text: Airy Clouds, you nourish fruits and rove the sky, you bring rain as you are driven everywhere by the wind.

title: HYMN ΚΒ΄. TO THE CLOUDS
text: Filled with blazing thunder, filled with water, you resound with awesome crashes in the air-filled vault of heaven as you are repelled by the attack of raging winds.

title: HYMN ΚΒ΄. TO THE CLOUDS
text: To you I offer my prayers: your dewy cloaks, blown by fair breezes, send fruit-nourishing rains to mother Earth.

title: HYMN ΚΓ΄. TO THE SEA
text: I call upon gray-eyed Tethys, bride of Okeanos, dark-veiled queen whose waves dance as they are blown onto the land by the sweet breezes.

spans.text: dance as they are blown onto the land

title: HYMN ΚΓ΄. TO THE SEA
text: You break your tall waves upon the rocky beaches, you are calmed by races that are gentle and smooth, you delight in ships, your waters feed wild beasts.

spans.text: calmed by races that are gentle and smooth

title: HYMN ΚΓ΄. TO THE SEA
text: Mother of Kypris, mother of dark clouds, mother of every spring round which nymphs swarm, hear me, O holy one, please help, send a fair tail wind to ships, O blessed one.

spans.text: send a fair tail wind to ships

title: HYMN ΚΔ΄. TO NEREUS
text: The sea's foundations are your realm, the abode of blue-black darkness, you exult in the beauty of your fifty daughters as they dance amid the waves.

spans.text: you exult in the beauty of your fifty daughters

title: HYMN ΚΔ΄. TO NEREUS
text: O Nereus, god of great renown, O foundation of the sea, O end of the earth, O beginning of all, Demeter's sacred throne trembles when you hold prisoner the gusty winds driven to your gloomy depths.

title: HYMN ΚΔ΄. TO NEREUS
text: O blessed one, ward off earthquakes and send to the initiates peace and prosperity.

title: HYMN ΚΕ΄. TO THE NEREIDS
text: O Nereus, god of great renown, O foundation of the sea, O end of the earth, O beginning of all, Demeter's sacred throne trembles when you hold prisoner the gusty winds driven to your gloomy depths.

title: HYMN ΚΕ΄. TO THE NEREIDS
text: O blessed one, ward off earthquakes and send to the initiates peace and prosperity and gentle-handed health.

title: HYMN ΚϚ΄. TO PROTEUS
text: I call upon Proteus, key-holding master of the sea, first-born, who showed the beginnings of all nature, changing matter into a great variety of forms.

spans.text: changing matter into a great variety of forms

title: HYMN ΚϚ΄. TO PROTEUS
text: Honored by all, he is wise, and he knows what is now, what was before, and what will be in the future.

spans.text: what will be in the future

title: HYMN ΚϚ΄. TO PROTEUS
text: He has all at his disposal, transformed far beyond all other immortals who dwell on snowy Olympos and fly through the air and over land and sea, for Physis was the first to place everything in Proteus.

spans.text: He has all at his disposal
transformed far beyond all other immortals
the first to place everything in Proteus

title: HYMN ΚϚ΄. TO PROTEUS
text: Father, attended by holy providence, visit the mystic initiates, and bring a good end to a life of industry and prosperity.

spans.text: bring a good end to a life of industry and prosperity
a life of industry and prosperity

title: HYMN ΚΖ΄. TO EARTH
text: Divine Earth, mother of men and of the blessed gods, you nourish all, you give all, you bring all to fruition, you destroy all.

spans.text: mother of men and of the blessed gods

title: HYMN ΚΖ΄. TO EARTH
text: When the season is fair, you teem with fruit and growing blossoms, O multi-formed maiden, seat of the immortal cosmos, in the pains of labor you bring forth all fruit.

spans.text: you teem with fruit and growing blossoms

title: HYMN ΚΖ΄. TO EARTH
text: Eternal, revered, deep-bosomed and blessed, your joy is the sweet breath of grass, O goddess bedecked with flowers, yours is the joy of the rain, the intricate realm of the stars revolves in endless and awesome flow.

spans.text: yours is the joy of the rain
the intricate realm of the stars
revolves in endless and awesome flow

title: HYMN ΚΖ΄. TO EARTH
text: O blessed goddess, may you multiply the delicious fruits, and may you and the beautiful Seasons grant me kindly favor.

title: HYMN ΚΗ΄. TO THE MOTHER OF THE GODS
text: Divine are your honors, O mother of the gods and nurturer of all.

title: HYMN ΚΗ΄. TO THE MOTHER OF THE GODS
text: Yoke your swift chariot drawn by bull-slaying lions, and join our prayers, O mighty goddess.

title: HYMN ΚΗ΄. TO THE MOTHER OF THE GODS
text: You bring things to pass, O many-named and revered one, you are queen of the sky; in the cosmos yours is the throne, the throne in the middle, because the earth is yours, and you give gentle nourishment to mortals.

title: HYMN ΚΗ΄. TO THE MOTHER OF THE GODS
text: Of you were born gods and men, you hold sway over the rivers and over all the sea.

title: HYMN ΚΗ΄. TO THE MOTHER OF THE GODS
text: Hestia is one of your names, they call you giver of prosperity, because you bestow on men all manner of blessings.

title: HYMN ΚΗ΄. TO THE MOTHER OF THE GODS
text: Come to this rite, queen whom the drum delights, all-taming savior of Phrygia, consort of Kronos, honored child of Sky, frenzy-loving nurturer of life, joyously and graciously visit our deeds of piety.

title: HYMN ΚΘ΄. TO HERMES
text: Hear me, Hermes, messenger of Zeus, son of Maia, almighty in heart, lord of the deceased, judge of contests, gentle and clever, O Argeiphontes, you are the guide of the flying sandals, a man-loving prophet to mortals.

title: HYMN ΚΘ΄. TO HERMES
text: A vigorous god, you delight in exercise and in deceit.

spans.text: you delight in exercise and in deceit

title: HYMN ΚΘ΄. TO HERMES
text: Interpreter of all you are, and a profiteer who frees us of cares, who holds in his hands the blameless tool of peace.

spans.text: a profiteer who frees us of cares

title: HYMN ΚΘ΄. TO HERMES
text: Lord of Korykos, blessed, helpful, and skilled in words, you assist in work and you are a friend of mortals in need.

title: HYMN ΚΘ΄. TO HERMES
text: You wield the dreaded, the respected weapon of speech.

spans.text: You wield the dreaded, the respected weapon of speech
the dreaded, the respected weapon of speech

title: HYMN ΚΘ΄. TO HERMES
text: Hear my prayer and grant a good end to a life of industry, gracious talk, and mindfulness.

title: HYMN Λ΄. TO PERSEPHONE
text: Persephone, blessed daughter of great Zeus, sole offspring of Demeter, come and accept this gracious sacrifice.

title: HYMN Λ΄. TO PERSEPHONE
text: Much-honored spouse of Plouton, discreet and life-giving, you command the gates of Hades in the bowels of the earth, lovely-tressed Praxidike, pure bloom of Deo, mother of the Erinyes, queen of the nether world, secretly sired by Zeus in clandestine union.

spans.text: you command the gates of Hades
in the bowels of the earth

title: HYMN Λ΄. TO PERSEPHONE
text: Mother of loud-roaring, many-shaped Eubouleus, radiant and luminous, playmate of the Seasons, revered and almighty, maiden rich in fruits, brilliant and horned, only-beloved of mortals, in spring you take your joy in the meadow of breezes, you show your holy figure in branches teeming with grass-green fruits, in autumn you were made a kidnapper's bride.

spans.text: in spring you take your joy in the meadow of breezes
you show your holy figure in branches teeming with grass-green fruits
in autumn you were made a kidnapper's bride

title: HYMN Λ΄. TO PERSEPHONE
text: You alone are life and death to toiling mortals, O Persephone, you nourish all, always, and kill them, too.

spans.text: You alone are life and death to toiling mortals

title: HYMN Λ΄. TO PERSEPHONE
text: Hearken, O blessed goddess, send forth the fruits of the earth as you blossom in peace, and in gentle-handed health bring a blessed life and a splendid old age to him who is sailing to your realm, O queen, and to mighty Plouton’s kingdom.

spans.text: him who is sailing to your realm

title: HYMN ΛΑ΄. TO DIONYSOS
text: I call upon loud-roaring, reveling Dionysos, primeval, two-natured, thrice-born Bacchic lord, savage, ineffable, secretive, two-horned and two-shaped, ivy-covered, bull-faced, warlike, howling, pure.

title: HYMN ΛΑ΄. TO DIONYSOS
text: You take raw flesh in triennial feasts, wrapped in foliage, decked with grape clusters, resourceful Eubouleus, immortal god sired by Zeus when he mated with Persephone in unspeakable union.

title: HYMN ΛΑ΄. TO DIONYSOS
text: Hearken to my voice, O blessed one, you and your fair-girdled nurses, breathe on me in a spirit of perfect kindness.

spans.text: in a spirit of perfect kindness

title: HYMN ΛΒ΄. HYMN TO THE KOURETES
text: Leaping Kouretes, stepping to the sound of arms, howling mountain men whose feet pound the ground, discordant is the lyre you strike as you pace, light of foot, O renowned marshals, O arm-carrying guards, priests in the train of a mother struck with mountain frenzy.

title: HYMN ΛΒ΄. HYMN TO THE KOURETES
text: Kindly visit the people who praise you with words, with joyous heart be gracious to the oxherd.

title: HYMN ΛΓ΄. TO ATHENE
text: Reverend Pallas, great Zeus bore you by himself, noble and blessed goddess, brave in the din of war.

spans.text: brave in the din of war

title: HYMN ΛΓ΄. TO ATHENE
text: Renowned and cave-haunting, spoken of and then ineffable, your domain is on wind-swept hilltops, shaded mountains, dells that charm your heart.

title: HYMN ΛΓ΄. TO ATHENE
text: Arms please you, and you strike men's souls with frenzy, O vigorous maiden, O horrid-tempered one, slayer of Gorgo, O blessed mother of the arts, you shun the bed of love, you bring madness to the wicked, you bring prudence to the virtuous, O impetuous one.

spans.text: O blessed mother of the arts

title: HYMN ΛΓ΄. TO ATHENE
text: Male and female, shrewd begetter of war, she-dragon of the many shapes, frenzy-loving, illustrious, destroyer of the Phlegraian Giants, driver of horses, victorious Tritogeneia, O goddess, you free us from suffering, day and night, ever into the small hours.

title: HYMN ΛΓ΄. TO ATHENE
text: Hear my prayer and give me a full measure of peace, of riches, and of health, accompanied by happy seasons, O gray-eyed and inventive queen, to whom many offer their prayers.

spans.text: to whom many offer their prayers

title: HYMN ΛΔ΄. TO NIKE
text: I call upon mighty Nike, beloved of mortals; she alone frees man from the eagerness for contest, from dissent, when men face each other in battle.

spans.text: men face each other in battle

title: HYMN ΛΔ΄. TO NIKE
text: In war you are the judge of deeds deserving prizes; sweet is the boast you grant after the onslaught.

spans.text: the judge of deeds deserving prizes

title: HYMN ΛΔ΄. TO NIKE
text: Nike, mistress of all, on your good name depends noble glory, glory that comes from the strife and teems with festivities.

spans.text: glory that comes from the strife

title: HYMN ΛΔ΄. TO NIKE
text: O blessed and beloved one, come with joy in your eyes, come for works of renown, bring me noble glory.

spans.text: come with joy in your eyes

title: HYMN ΛΕ΄. TO APOLLON
text: Come, O blessed Paian, O slayer of Tityos, O Phoibos, O Lykoreus, giver of riches, illustrious dweller of Memphis, O god to whom we cry “Ië,” O Titan and Pythian god, yours are the golden lyre, the seeds, and the plows.

title: HYMN ΛΕ΄. TO APOLLON
text: Grynean, Sminthian, slayer of Python, Delphic diviner, wild, light-bringing, lovable god you are, O glorious youth.

title: HYMN ΛΕ΄. TO APOLLON
text: You shoot your arrows from afar, you lead the Muses into dance, O holy one, you are Bacchos, Didymeus, Loxias, too, lord of Delos, you are the eye that sees all, you bring light to mortals, your hair is golden, your oracular utterance is clear.

spans.text: You shoot your arrows from afar
you lead the Muses into dance

title: HYMN ΛΕ΄. TO APOLLON
text: Hear me with kindly heart as I pray for people.

title: HYMN ΛΕ΄. TO APOLLON
text: You gaze upon all the ethereal vastness, upon the rich earth you look through the twilight.

spans.text: You gaze upon all the ethereal vastness

title: HYMN ΛΕ΄. TO APOLLON
text: In the quiet darkness of a night lit with stars you see earth's roots below, you hold the bounds of the whole world; the beginning and the end to come are yours.

spans.text: the bounds of the whole world

title: HYMN ΛΕ΄. TO APOLLON
text: You make everything bloom with your versatile lyre, you harmonize the poles, now reaching the highest pitch, now the lowest, now again with a Doric mode, harmoniously balancing the poles, you keep the living races distinct.

title: HYMN ΛΕ΄. TO APOLLON
text: You have infused harmony into the lot of all men, giving them an equal measure of winter and summer: the lowest notes you strike in the winter, the highest notes you make distinct in the summer, your mode is Doric for spring's lovely and blooming season.

spans.text: equal measure of winter and summer

title: HYMN ΛΕ΄. TO APOLLON
text: This is why mortals call you lord and Pan, the two-horned god who sends the whistling winds; it is for this you have the master seal of the entire cosmos.

title: HYMN ΛΕ΄. TO APOLLON
text: O blessed one, hear the suppliant voice of the initiates and save them.

title: HYMN ΛϚ΄. TO LETO
text: Dark-veiled Leto, revered goddess, mother of twins, great-souled daughter of Koios, queen to whom many pray, to your lot fell the birth pains for Zeus' fair children, you bore Phoibos and arrow-pouring Artemis, her on Ortygia, him on rocky Delos.

title: HYMN ΛϚ΄. TO LETO
text: Hear, lady goddess, come with favor in your heart to bring a sweet end to this all-holy rite.

title: HYMN ΛΖ΄. TO ARTEMIS
text: Hear me, O queen, Zeus' daughter of many names, Titanic and Bacchic, revered, renowned archer, torch-bearing goddess bringing light to all, Diktynna, helper at childbirth, you help women in labor, though you know not what labor is.

title: HYMN ΛΖ΄. TO ARTEMIS
text: O frenzy-loving huntress, you loosen girdles and drive distress away; swift arrow-pouring goddess of the outdoors, you roam in the night.

spans.text: swift arrow-pouring goddess of the outdoors

title: HYMN ΛΖ΄. TO ARTEMIS
text: Fame-bringing and affable, redeeming and masculine in appearance, Orthia, goddess of swift birth, you are a nurturer of mortal youths, immortal and yet of this earth, you slay wild beasts, O blessed one, your realm is in the mountain forest, you hunt deer.

spans.text: immortal and yet of this earth
your realm is in the mountain forest

title: HYMN ΛΖ΄. TO ARTEMIS
text: O revered and mighty queen of all, fair-blossomed, eternal, sylvan, dog-loving, many-shaped lady of Kydonia, come, dear goddess, as savior to all the initiates, accessible to all, bringing forth the beautiful fruit of the earth, lovely peace, and fair-tressed health.

spans.text: O revered and mighty queen of all
bringing forth the beautiful fruit of the earth

title: HYMN ΛΖ΄. TO ARTEMIS
text: May you dispatch diseases and pain to the peaks of the mountains.

title: HYMN ΛΗ΄. TO THE TITANS
text: Titans, glorious children of Sky and Earth, ancestors of our fathers, you dwell down below in Tartarean homes, in the bowels of the earth.

title: HYMN ΛΗ΄. TO THE TITANS
text: From you are descended all toiling mortals, the brood of the sea and of the land, then the brood of the birds, of all generations of the world born of you.

title: HYMN ΛΗ΄. TO THE TITANS
text: I call upon you to banish harsh anger if some earthly forefather of mine stormed your homes.

title: HYMN ΛΘ΄. TO THE KOURETES
text: Bronze-beating Kouretes, the weapons of Ares are yours.

title: HYMN ΛΘ΄. TO THE KOURETES
text: Dwellers of heaven, of earth and sea, thrice-blessed ones, life-giving breezes, glorious saviors of the world, you dwell in the sacred land of Samothrace, you ward off dangers for mortals roaming the seas, you were first to set up sacred rites for mortals.

spans.text: Dwellers of heaven, of earth and sea
first to set up sacred rites for mortals

title: HYMN ΛΘ΄. TO THE KOURETES
text: O immortal Kouretes, the weapons of Ares are yours.

title: HYMN ΛΘ΄. TO THE KOURETES
text: You rule Okeanos, you rule the sea and the forests, the earth resounds with the pounding of your nimble feet, and with the glories in your gleaming armor.

spans.text: the pounding of your nimble feet
the glories in your gleaming armor

title: HYMN ΛΘ΄. TO THE KOURETES
text: All wild beasts cringe at your onrush, the din and the shouts rise heavenward, the dust from your feet, as you march briskly, reaches the clouds; every flower is in bloom.

title: HYMN ΛΘ΄. TO THE KOURETES
text: Immortal gods, you nurture, you also destroy when you fret angrily over mankind, you ruin livelihoods and possessions, you ruin men themselves ... the great deep-eddying sea groans, lofty trees are uprooted, they fall upon the earth, the noisy tremor of the leaves echoes in the sky.

spans.text: when you fret angrily over mankind
the noisy tremor of the leaves

title: HYMN ΛΘ΄. TO THE KOURETES
text: Kouretes, Korybantes, mighty lords, masters of Samothrace, true Dioskouroi, ever-blowing breezes, soul-nurturing and airy, you're called celestial twins on Olympos.

title: HYMN ΛΘ΄. TO THE KOURETES
text: Gentle saviors, you bring fair breezes and clear weather, nurturers of seasons and of fruits, breathe upon us, O lords.

title: HYMN Μ΄. TO KORYBAS
text: I call upon the greatest king of eternal earth, blessed Korybas, the warlike, the one of the forbidding countenance, the nocturnal Koures who saves us from dreadful fear.

spans.text: the greatest king of eternal earth
the one of the forbidding countenance

title: HYMN Μ΄. TO KORYBAS
text: Korybas, you save us from fantasies as you wander in deserted places.

title: HYMN Μ΄. TO KORYBAS
text: Many are the shapes, O lord, of your twofold divinity; your blood is tainted with the murder of twin brothers.

title: HYMN Μ΄. TO KORYBAS
text: You follow Deo's thinking, you changed your holy form into the shape of a savage, dark dragon.

spans.text: the shape of a savage, dark dragon

title: HYMN Μ΄. TO KORYBAS
text: O blessed one, hear our voices, banish harsh anger, free from fantasies souls stunned by compulsions.

title: HYMN ΜΑ΄. TO ELEUSINIAN DEMETER
text: Deo, divine mother of all, goddess of many names, revered Demeter, nurturer of youths, giver of prosperity and wealth, you nourish the ears of corn, O giver of all, you delight in peace and in toilsome labor.

spans.text: you nourish the ears of corn

title: HYMN ΜΑ΄. TO ELEUSINIAN DEMETER
text: Present at sowing, heaping, and threshing, O spirit of the unripe fruit, you dwell in the sacred valley of Eleusis.

title: HYMN ΜΑ΄. TO ELEUSINIAN DEMETER
text: Charming and lovely, you give sustenance to all mortals; you were the first to yoke the ploughing ox, the first to send up from below a rich, a lovely harvest for mortals.

spans.text: you give sustenance to all mortals
the first to yoke the ploughing ox
the first to send up from below a rich, a lovely harvest for mortals

title: HYMN ΜΑ΄. TO ELEUSINIAN DEMETER
text: You are growth and blooming, O illustrious companion of Bromios, torch-bearing and pure, you delight in the summer's yield.

title: HYMN ΜΑ΄. TO ELEUSINIAN DEMETER
text: From beneath the earth you appear, gentle to all, O holy and youth-nurturing lover of children and of fair offspring.

spans.text: O holy and youth-nurturing lover of children and of fair offspring

title: HYMN ΜΑ΄. TO ELEUSINIAN DEMETER
text: You yoke your chariot to bridled dragons, round your throne you whirl and howl in ecstasy.

spans.text: you yoke your chariot to bridled dragons

title: HYMN ΜΑ΄. TO ELEUSINIAN DEMETER
text: You are an only daughter, but you have many children and many powers over mortals; the variety of flowers reflect your myriad faces and your sacred blossoms.

title: HYMN ΜΑ΄. TO ELEUSINIAN DEMETER
text: Come, O blessed and pure one, come with the fruits of summer, bring peace, bring the welcome rule of law, bring riches, too, and prosperity, and bring health that governs all.

title: HYMN ΜΒ΄. TO MOTHER ANTAIA
text: Queen Antaia, goddess and many-named mother of immortal gods and of mortal men, weary from searching, weary from wandering far and wide, you once ended your fast in the valley of Eleusis, you came to Hades for noble Persephone.

spans.text: weary from wandering far and wide

title: HYMN ΜΒ΄. TO MOTHER ANTAIA
text: Your guide was the innocent child of Dysaules, who brought the news of pure Chthonic Zeus' holy union; you bore divine Euboulos by yielding to human need.

title: HYMN ΜΒ΄. TO MOTHER ANTAIA
text: O goddess, O queen to whom many pray, I beseech you to come graciously to your pious initiate.

title: HYMN ΜΓ΄. TO MISE
text: I call upon law-giving Dionysos, who carried the fennel stalk, unforgettable and many-named seed of Eubouleus, I call upon the sacred and holy, upon the ineffable queen Mise, whose twofold nature is male and female.

spans.text: unforgettable and many-named seed of Eubouleus

title: HYMN ΜΓ΄. TO MISE
text: Redeeming Iacchos, lord, I summon you, whether you delight in Eleusis in your fragrant temple, or with Mother you partake of mystic rites in Phrygia, or you rejoice in Kypros with fair-wreathed Kythereia, or yet you exult in fields wheat-bearing and hallowed along Egypt's river with your divine mother, the revered and black-robed Isis, as your train of nurses tends to your needs.

title: HYMN ΜΓ΄. TO MISE
text: Lady, kindheartedly come to the noble contests of our initiation.

title: HYMN ΜΔ΄. TO THE SEASONS
text: Seasons, daughters of Themis, daughters of Lord Zeus, Eunomia and Dike and thrice-blessed Eirene, pure spirits of spring, of blossoming meadows, you are found in every color, in all scents wafted by the breezes.

title: HYMN ΜΔ΄. TO THE SEASONS
text: Ever-blooming, revolving, and sweet-faced, O Seasons, you cloak yourselves with the dew of luxuriant flowers.

spans.text: cloak yourselves with the dew of luxuriant flowers

title: HYMN ΜΔ΄. TO THE SEASONS
text: At play you are companions of holy Persephone, when the Fates and the Graces in circling dances come forth to the light, pleasing Zeus and their mother, giver of fruits.

title: HYMN ΜΔ΄. TO THE SEASONS
text: Come to the new initiates and their holy and reverent rites, bring perfect seasons for the growth of goodly fruit.

title: HYMN ΜΕ΄. TO SEMELE
text: I call upon the daughter of Kadmos, queen of all, fair Semele of the lovely tresses, of the full bosom, mother of thyrsos-bearing, joyous Dionysos.

title: HYMN ΜΕ΄. TO SEMELE
text: She was driven to great pain by the blazing thunderbolt, which, through the counsels of Kronian Zeus, the immortal god, burned her.

spans.text: through the counsels of Kronian Zeus

title: HYMN ΜΕ΄. TO SEMELE
text: Noble Persephone granted her honors among mortal men, honors given every third year.

title: HYMN ΜΕ΄. TO SEMELE
text: For all mortal men reenact your travail for your son Bacchos: the sacred ritual of the table, the ritual of the holy mysteries.

spans.text: the sacred ritual of the table
the ritual of the holy mysteries

title: HYMN ΜϚ΄. HYMN TO DIONYSOS BASSAREUS AND TRIENNIAL
text: Come blessed Dionysos, bull-faced god conceived in fire, Bassareus and Bacchos, many-named master of all.

title: HYMN ΜϚ΄. HYMN TO DIONYSOS BASSAREUS AND TRIENNIAL
text: You delight in bloody swords, you delight in the holy Maenads, as you howl throughout Olympos, all-roaring and frenzied Bacchos.

title: HYMN ΜϚ΄. HYMN TO DIONYSOS BASSAREUS AND TRIENNIAL
text: Armed with the thyrsos, wrathful in the extreme, you are honored by all gods and all men who dwell upon the earth.

title: HYMN ΜϚ΄. HYMN TO DIONYSOS BASSAREUS AND TRIENNIAL
text: Come, blessed and leaping god, bring abundant joy to all.

title: HYMN ΜΖ΄. TO LIKNITES
text: I summon to these prayers Dionysos Liknites, born at Nysa, blossoming, beloved and kindly Bacchos, nursling of the Nymphs and of fair-wreathed Aphrodite.

title: HYMN ΜΖ΄. TO LIKNITES
text: The forests once felt your feet quiver in the dance as frenzy drove you and the graceful Nymphs on and on.

title: HYMN ΜΖ΄. TO LIKNITES
text: The counsels of Zeus brought you to noble Persephone, who reared you to be loved by the deathless gods.

spans.text: to be loved by the deathless gods

title: HYMN ΜΖ΄. TO LIKNITES
text: Kindheartedly come, O blessed one, accept the gift of this sacrifice.

title: HYMN ΜΗ΄. TO PERIKIONIOS
text: I call upon Bacchos Perikionios, giver of wine; he enveloped all of Kadmos' house, with his might he harnessed, he calmed the heaving earth, when the blazing thunderbolt, when the raging gale stirred all the land, as everyone's bonds sprang loose.

title: HYMN ΜΗ΄. TO PERIKIONIOS
text: Blessed reveler, come with joyful heart.

title: HYMN ΜΘ΄. TO SABAZIOS
text: Hear me, father Sabazios, son of Kronos, illustrious god, you sewed into your thigh Bacchic Dionysos, the roaring Eiraphiotes, that he might come whole to noble Tmolos by the side of fair-cheeked Hipta.

title: HYMN ΜΘ΄. TO SABAZIOS
text: O blessed ruler of Phrygia, supreme king of all, come kindheartedly to the aid of the initiates.

spans.text: come kindheartedly to the aid of the initiates

title: HYMN Ν΄. TO HIPTA
text: I call upon Hipta, nurse of Bacchos, maiden possessed, in mystic rites she takes part, she exults in the worship of pure Sabos and in the dances of roaring Iacchos.

title: HYMN Ν΄. TO HIPTA
text: O queen and chthonic mother, hear my prayer, whether you are on Ida, Phrygia's sacred mountain, or you take your pleasure on Tmolos, fair seat of the Lydians, come to these rites with joy on your holy face.

title: HYMN ΝΑ΄. TO LYSIOS LENAIOS
text: Hear, O blessed son of Zeus and of two mothers, Bacchos of the vintage, unforgettable seed, many-named and redeeming daimōn, holy offspring of the gods, reveling Bacchos, born of secrecy, plump giver of many joys, of fruits which grow well.

title: HYMN ΝΑ΄. TO LYSIOS LENAIOS
text: Mighty and many-shaped god, you burst forth from the earth to reach the wine press, to become a healer for men's pain, O sacred blossom!

spans.text: you burst forth from the earth
to become a healer for men's pain

title: HYMN ΝΑ΄. TO LYSIOS LENAIOS
text: A sorrow-hating joy to mortals, O lovely-haired..., a redeemer and a reveler you are, your thyrsos drives to frenzy, you are kind-hearted to all gods and mortals who see your light.

title: HYMN ΝΑ΄. TO LYSIOS LENAIOS
text: I call upon you now, come, O sweet bringer of fruit.

title: HYMN ΝΒ΄. TO THE NYMPHS
text: O Nymphs, daughters of great-hearted Okeanos, you dwell inside the earth's damp caves; you are as secret as your paths, O joyous, O chthonic nurses of Bacchos.

title: HYMN ΝΒ΄. TO THE NYMPHS
text: You nurture fruits, you haunt meadows, O sprightly and pure travelers of the winding roads, who delight in caves and grottos.

spans.text: O sprightly and pure travelers of the winding roads
who delight in caves and grottos

title: HYMN ΝΒ΄. TO THE NYMPHS
text: Swift, light-footed, and clothed in dew, you frequent springs, visible and invisible, in ravines and among flowers you shout and frisk with Pan upon mountainsides, gliding down on rocks, you hum with clear voice.

spans.text: Swift, light-footed, and clothed in dew
you shout and frisk with Pan

title: HYMN ΝΒ΄. TO THE NYMPHS
text: O mountain-haunting maidens of the fields, of gushing springs and of woodlands, sweet-smelling virgins, clothed in white, fresh as the breeze, herds of goats, pastures, splendid fruit, you protect; wild animals love you.

title: HYMN ΝΒ΄. TO THE NYMPHS
text: Though you are tender, cold delights you; you feed many, you help them grow, Hamadryad maidens, playful, water-loving.

title: HYMN ΝΒ΄. TO THE NYMPHS
text: Spring is your joy, O Nysian and frenzied, O healing ones, in the company of Bacchos and Deo, you bring grace to mortals.

title: HYMN ΝΒ΄. TO THE NYMPHS
text: Come to this blessed sacrifice with joyful heart, pour streams of pure rain during the grain-giving seasons.

title: HYMN ΝΓ΄. TO THE GOD OF TRIENNIAL FEASTS
text: I call upon you, blessed, many-named, frenzied Bacchos, bull-horned, Nysian, Lysios, Lenaios, conceived in fire.

title: HYMN ΝΓ΄. TO THE GOD OF TRIENNIAL FEASTS
text: Nourished in the thigh, Liknites, you lead torch-lit processions, you lead them in the night, O filleted, O thyrsos-shaking Eubouleus.

spans.text: you lead them in the night

title: HYMN ΝΓ΄. TO THE GOD OF TRIENNIAL FEASTS
text: Your nature three-fold, your rites ineffable, O secret offspring of Zeus, primeval, Erikepaios, father and son of the gods, you take raw flesh, and sceptered you lead us into the madness of revel and dance, into the frenzy of triennial feasts that bestow calm on us.

spans.text: father and son of the gods
you lead us into the madness of revel and dance
into the frenzy of triennial feasts

title: HYMN ΝΓ΄. TO THE GOD OF TRIENNIAL FEASTS
text: You burst forth from the earth in a blaze..., O son of two mothers, horned and clad in fawn skin, you roam the mountains, O lord worshipped in annual feasts.

spans.text: burst forth from the earth in a blaze
horned and clad in fawn skin
O lord worshipped in annual feasts

title: HYMN ΝΓ΄. TO THE GOD OF TRIENNIAL FEASTS
text: Paian of the golden spear, nursling, decked with grapes, Bassaros, exulting in ivy, followed by many maidens..., joyous and all-abounding, come, O blessed one, to the initiates.

title: HYMN ΝΔ΄. TO THE GOD OF ANNUAL FEASTS
text: I call upon Bacchos, the god we worship annually, chthonic Dionysos, together with the fair-tressed Nymphs he is roused.

title: HYMN ΝΔ΄. TO THE GOD OF ANNUAL FEASTS
text: In the sacred halls of Persephone he slumbers and puts to sleep pure Bacchic time, every third year.

title: HYMN ΝΔ΄. TO THE GOD OF ANNUAL FEASTS
text: When he himself stirs up the triennial revel again, he sings a hymn together with his fair-girdled nurses.

title: HYMN ΝΔ΄. TO THE GOD OF ANNUAL FEASTS
text: As the seasons revolve, he puts to sleep and wakes up the years.

title: HYMN ΝΔ΄. TO THE GOD OF ANNUAL FEASTS
text: O blessed and fruit-giving Bacchos, O horned spirit of the unripe fruit, come to this most sacred rite with a glow of joy on your face, come teeming with fruit that is holy and perfect.

spans.text: horned spirit of the unripe fruit
glow of joy on your face
teeming with fruit that is holy and perfect

title: HYMN ΝΕ΄. TO SILENOS SATYROS AND THE BACCHAE
text: Hear me, foster father of Bacchos, father and nurturer, best of the Silenoi, honored by all the gods, honored by mortal men in the same triennial feasts.

title: HYMN ΝΕ΄. TO SILENOS SATYROS AND THE BACCHAE
text: Pure and prized marshal of the pastoral band, wakeful reveler and companion of the fair-girt nurses, leader of the ivy-crowned Naiads and of the Bacchantes, take all the Satyrs, half-men, half-beast, come howling to the Bacchic lord.

spans.text: Pure and prized marshal of the pastoral band
come howling to the Bacchic lord

title: HYMN ΝΕ΄. TO SILENOS SATYROS AND THE BACCHAE
text: The Bacchantes escort the holy Lenaian procession in sacred litanies revealing torch-lit rites, shouting, thyrsos-loving, finding calm in the revels.

title: HYMN ΝϚ΄. TO APHRODITE
text: Heavenly, smiling Aphrodite, praised in many hymns, sea-born revered goddess of generation, you like the night-long revel, you couple lovers at night, O scheming mother of Necessity.

title: HYMN ΝϚ΄. TO APHRODITE
text: Everything comes from you: you have yoked the world, you control all three realms, you give birth to all, to everything in heaven, to everything upon the fruitful earth, to everything in the depths of the sea, O venerable companion of Bacchos.

spans.text: everything in the depths of the sea

title: HYMN ΝϚ΄. TO APHRODITE
text: You delight in festivities, O bride-like mother of the Erotes, O Persuasion, whose joy is in the bed of love, secretive giver of grace, visible and invisible, lovely-tressed daughter of a noble father, bridal feast companion of the gods, sceptered, she-wolf, beloved and man-loving, giver of birth and life.

spans.text: O bride-like mother of the Erotes
whose joy is in the bed of love
lovely-tressed daughter of a noble father
bridal feast companion of the gods

title: HYMN ΝϚ΄. TO APHRODITE
text: Your maddening love-charms yoke mortals, they yoke the many races of beasts to unbridled passion.

title: HYMN ΝϚ΄. TO APHRODITE
text: Come, O goddess born in Kypros: you may be on Olympos, O queen, exulting in the beauty of your face, you may be in Syria, country of fine frankincense, you may be driving your golden chariot in the plain, you may lord it over Egypt's fertile river bed.

title: HYMN ΝϚ΄. TO APHRODITE
text: Come, whether you ride your swan-drawn chariot over the sea's billows, joining the creatures of the deep as they dance in circles, or on land in the company of the dark-faced nymphs as light-footed they frisk over the sandy beaches.

title: HYMN ΝϚ΄. TO APHRODITE
text: Come lady, even if you are in Kypros that cherishes you, where fair maidens and chaste brides throughout the year sing of you, O blessed one, as they sing of immortal, pure Adonis.

title: HYMN ΝϚ΄. TO APHRODITE
text: Come, O beautiful, O comely goddess, I summon you with holy words, I summon you with a pious soul.

title: HYMN ΝΖ΄. TO ADONIS
text: Hear my prayer, O best, O many-named god.

title: HYMN ΝΖ΄. TO ADONIS
text: Fine-haired, solitary, ever bursting with lovely song, Eubouleus, many-shaped, noble nurturer of all, male and female in one ... unwithering bloom, O Adonis, you vanish and then shine again in the fair season's turn.

title: HYMN ΝΖ΄. TO ADONIS
text: Two-horned spirit of growth, much loved and wept for, fair one, joyful hunter, god of the luxuriant mane, desire is in you, O sweet blossom, O son of Aphrodite and Eros, born on the bed of lovely-tressed Persephone.

spans.text: O son of Aphrodite and Eros
born on the bed of lovely-tressed Persephone

title: HYMN ΝΖ΄. TO ADONIS
text: You dwell deep in murky Tartaros, then again toward Olympos you carry your blossoming body.

spans.text: You dwell deep in murky Tartaros

title: HYMN ΝΖ΄. TO ADONIS
text: Come, O blessed one, bring earth's fruits to the initiates.

title: HYMN ΝΗ΄. TO CHTHONIC HERMES
text: You dwell on the road all must take, the road of no return, by the Kokytos, you guide the souls of mortals to the nether gloom.

title: HYMN ΝΗ΄. TO CHTHONIC HERMES
text: Hermes, offspring of Dionysos who revels in the dance, and of Aphrodite, the Paphian maiden of the fluttering eyelids, you haunt the sacred house of Persephone as guide throughout the earth of ill-fated souls, the souls you bring to their destined harbor when their time has come; you charm them with your sacred wand, you give them sleep from which you rouse them again.

spans.text: the Paphian maiden of the fluttering eyelids
guide throughout the earth of ill-fated souls
the souls you bring to their destined harbor
you charm them with your sacred wand
you give them sleep from which you rouse them again

title: HYMN ΝΗ΄. TO CHTHONIC HERMES
text: It is to you indeed that Persephone gave the high office throughout broad Tartaros to lead the way for the everlasting souls of men.

title: HYMN ΝΗ΄. TO CHTHONIC HERMES
text: O blessed one, grant a good end for the labors of the initiates.

title: HYMN ΝΘ΄. TO EROS
text: I call upon you, great, pure, lovely and sweet Eros, winged archer who runs swiftly on a path of fire, who plays together with gods and mortal men.

spans.text: who runs swiftly on a path of fire
who plays together with gods and mortal men

title: HYMN ΝΘ΄. TO EROS
text: Inventive, two-natured, you are master of all: of the sky's ether, of the sea and the land, of the all-begetting winds, which for mortals the goddess of grass and grain nurtures, of all that lies in Tartaros, of all that lies in the roaring sea; you alone govern the course of all these.

spans.text: the goddess of grass and grain
govern the course of all these

title: HYMN ΝΘ΄. TO EROS
text: O blessed one, come to the initiates with pure thought, banish from them vile impulses.

title: HYMN Ξ΄. TO THE FATES
text: Boundless Fates, dear children of dark Night, hear my prayer, O many-named dwellers on the lake of heaven, where the frozen water is broken by night's warmth in the shady hollow of a sleek cave; from there you fly to the vast earth, home of mortals, from there, clothed in purple, you march toward men, whose noble aims match their vain hopes, in the realm of the dead, where glory drives her chariot on all over the earthbeyond the ends of Justice, of anxious hope, of primeval law, of the measureless principle of order.

title: HYMN Ξ΄. TO THE FATES
text: In life Fate alone watches; the other immortals who dwell on the peaks of snowy Olympos do not, except for Zeus' perfect eye.

spans.text: who dwell on the peaks of snowy Olympos

title: HYMN Ξ΄. TO THE FATES
text: Fate and Zeus' mind know all things for all time.

title: HYMN Ξ΄. TO THE FATES
text: I pray to you to come, gently and kindly, Atropos, Lakhesis, Klotho, offspring of noble stock.

spans.text: I pray to you to come, gently and kindly

title: HYMN Ξ΄. TO THE FATES
text: Airy, invisible, inexorable, ever indestructible, you give all and take all, being to men the same as necessity.

spans.text: you give all and take all

title: HYMN Ξ΄. TO THE FATES
text: Fates, hear my prayers, receive my libations, come gently to the initiates, free them from pain.

title: HYMN ΞΑ΄. TO THE GRACES
text: Hear me, O illustrious, O renowned Graces, daughters of Zeus and full-bosomed Eunomia, Aglaia, Thalia, blessed Euphrosyne, lovely, wise, and pure mothers of joy, many-shaped, ever-blooming, beloved of mortals.

title: HYMN ΞΑ΄. TO THE GRACES
text: We pray that each in her turn with a flower's beauty on her face, enchanting, come, ever gentle, to the initiates to bring them prosperity.

spans.text: We pray that each in her turn with a flower's beauty on her face

title: HYMN ΞΒ΄. HYMN TO NEMESIS
text: Nemesis, I call upon you, O goddess, O great queen, your all-seeing eye looks upon the lives of man's many races.

spans.text: the lives of man's many races

title: HYMN ΞΒ΄. HYMN TO NEMESIS
text: Eternal and revered, you alone rejoice in the just, you change and vary, you shift your word.

spans.text: you alone rejoice in the just

title: HYMN ΞΒ΄. HYMN TO NEMESIS
text: All who bear the yoke of mortality fear you, you care about the thoughts of all; the arrogant soul, the reckless one, finds no escape.

spans.text: All who bear the yoke of mortality
you care about the thoughts of all

title: HYMN ΞΒ΄. HYMN TO NEMESIS
text: You see all, you hear all, you arbitrate all.

title: HYMN ΞΒ΄. HYMN TO NEMESIS
text: O sublime deity, in whom dwells justice for men, come, blessed and pure one, ever helpful to the initiates, grant nobility of mind, put an end to repulsive thoughts, thoughts unholy, fickle and haughty.

title: HYMN ΞΓ΄. TO DIKE
text: I sing of the all-seeing eye of comely and radiant Dike, who is seated upon the sacred throne of lord Zeus.

title: HYMN ΞΓ΄. TO DIKE
text: From heaven you watch the lives of the many human races, you crush the unjust with just retribution, matching things lawless through the truth of equality.

spans.text: the lives of the many human races

title: HYMN ΞΓ΄. TO DIKE
text: For whenever base opinions prevail in difficult verdicts, because men wish more than is fair, you intervene and rouse justice against her foes.

title: HYMN ΞΓ΄. TO DIKE
text: An enemy of the unjust, you are a gentle goddess to the just.

spans.text: you are a gentle goddess to the just

title: HYMN ΞΓ΄. TO DIKE
text: O goddess, come evenhanded to thoughts that are noble, until that fated day descends on my life.

title: HYMN ΞΔ΄. TO JUSTICE
text: O paragon of justice to mortals, blessed and beloved one, you take equal pleasure in all men who are just.

title: HYMN ΞΔ΄. TO JUSTICE
text: Honored by all and blissful, O bold, O lofty Justice, you are pure of thought, you reward propriety, your own conscience is unbreakable for you break all who do not submit to your yoke, but ... in their greed upset the balance of your mighty scales.

spans.text: break all who do not submit to your yoke
upset the balance of your mighty scales

title: HYMN ΞΔ΄. TO JUSTICE
text: Dauntless, charming, a lover of revel loved by all, you rejoice in peace, you strive for a life that is stable.

spans.text: you strive for a life that is stable

title: HYMN ΞΔ΄. TO JUSTICE
text: You loath unfairness, but fairness delights you; in you knowledge of virtue reaches its noble goal.

title: HYMN ΞΔ΄. TO JUSTICE
text: Hear, O goddess, rightly shatter wicked men, so that mortals who eat of the fruits of this earth and also all living creatures nursed in the bosom of Earth, the divine mother, nursed in the bosom of sea-dwelling Zeus, may follow a path both balanced and noble.

title: HYMN ΞΕ΄. HYMN TO NOMOS
text: Upon the holy lord of men and gods I call, heavenly Nomos, who arranges the stars and sets a fair limit between the earth and the waters of the sea; it is his laws that ever preserve nature's balance, obedient and steady.

spans.text: the holy lord of men and gods

title: HYMN ΞΕ΄. HYMN TO NOMOS
text: Journeying on the heavens, he brings the laws from above, with a roar he drives out malicious envy.

title: HYMN ΞΕ΄. HYMN TO NOMOS
text: Nomos summons a good end to mortal life, he alone steers the course of everything that breathes, ever the steadfast companion of righteous thought.

spans.text: the course of everything that breathes

title: HYMN ΞΕ΄. HYMN TO NOMOS
text: Primeval and wise, in peace he shares the same house with all who abide by the law, bringing harsh vengeance upon the lawless.

spans.text: all who abide by the law

title: HYMN ΞΕ΄. HYMN TO NOMOS
text: O blessed bringer of prosperity, beloved of all and honored, with kindness of heart send forth memory of you, O mighty one.

title: HYMN ΞϚ΄. TO ARES
text: Unbreakable, strong-spirited, mighty, powerful daimon, delighting in arms, indomitable, man-slaying, wall-battering, lord Ares, yours is the din of arms.

spans.text: yours is the din of arms

title: HYMN ΞϚ΄. TO ARES
text: Ever bespattered with blood, you find joy in killing in the fray of battle, O horrid one, your desire is for the rude clash of swords and spears.

spans.text: your desire is for the rude clash of swords and spears
rude clash of swords and spears

title: HYMN ΞϚ΄. TO ARES
text: Stay the rage, stay the strife, relax pain's grip on my soul, yield to the wish of Kypris, yield to the revels of Lyaios, exchange the might of arms for the works of Deo, yearning for youth-nurturing peace, bliss-bringing peace.

spans.text: relax pain's grip on my soul

title: HYMN ΞΖ΄. TO HEPHAISTOS
text: Hephaistos, powerful and strong-spirited, unwearying fire, shining in the gleam of flames, a god bringing light to mortals, mighty-handed, eternal artisan, worker, part of the cosmos, blameless element, most sublime, all-eating, all-taming, all-haunting— ether, sun, stars, moon, pure light: all these parts of Hephaistos are revealed to mortals.

spans.text: shining in the gleam of flames

title: HYMN ΞΖ΄. TO HEPHAISTOS
text: All homes, all cities, all nations are yours.

title: HYMN ΞΖ΄. TO HEPHAISTOS
text: O mighty giver of many blessings, you dwell in human bodies.

spans.text: O mighty giver of many blessings

title: HYMN ΞΖ΄. TO HEPHAISTOS
text: Hear me, lord, as I summon you to this holy libation, that you may always come gentle to joyful deeds, end the savage rage of untiring fire as nature itself burns in our own bodies.

spans.text: you may always come gentle to joyful deeds
end the savage rage of untiring fire

title: HYMN ΞΗ΄. TO ASKLEPIOS
text: Asklepios, lord Paian, healer of all, you charm away the pains of men who suffer.

spans.text: you charm away the pains of men who suffer

title: HYMN ΞΗ΄. TO ASKLEPIOS
text: Come, mighty and soothing, bring health, put an end to sickness, then to the harsh fate of death.

title: HYMN ΞΗ΄. TO ASKLEPIOS
text: O blessed spirit of joyful growth, O helper, you ward off evil, honored and mighty son of Phoibos Apollon.

spans.text: honored and mighty son of Phoibos Apollon

title: HYMN ΞΗ΄. TO ASKLEPIOS
text: Enemy of disease, consort of Hygieia the blameless, come as savior, O blessed one, bring life to a good end.

spans.text: bring life to a good end

title: HYMN ΞΘ΄. TO HYGEIA
text: Charming queen of all, lovely and blooming, blessed Hygeia, mother of all, bringer of bliss, hear me.

title: HYMN ΞΘ΄. TO HYGEIA
text: Through you vanish the illnesses that afflict man, through you every house blossoms to the fullness of joy.

title: HYMN ΞΘ΄. TO HYGEIA
text: The arts thrive when the world desires you, O queen, loathed by Hades, the destroyer of souls.

title: HYMN ΞΘ΄. TO HYGEIA
text: Apart from you all is without profit for men: wealth, the sweet giver of abundance for those who feast, fails, and man never reaches the many pains of old age.

spans.text: all is without profit for men
the many pains of old age

title: HYMN ΞΘ΄. TO HYGEIA
text: Goddess, come, ever-helpful to the initiates, keep away the evil distress of unbearable diseases.

title: HYMN Ο΄. TO THE ERINYES
text: Hear, Tisiphone, Allekto, noble Megaira, revered goddesses whose Bacchic cries resound.

title: HYMN Ο΄. TO THE ERINYES
text: Nocturnal and clandestine, you live deep down in the dank cave by the sacred water of the Styx.

spans.text: you live deep down in the dank cave
the sacred water of the Styx

title: HYMN Ο΄. TO THE ERINYES
text: Men's unholy designs do incur your anger; rabid and arrogant, you howl over Necessity's dictates, clothed in animal skins, you cause the deep pains of retribution.

spans.text: you cause the deep pains of retribution

title: HYMN Ο΄. TO THE ERINYES
text: O dreaded maidens of the thousand faces, your realm is in Hades, phantoms airy, invisible, swift as thought you are.

spans.text: dreaded maidens of the thousand faces

title: HYMN Ο΄. TO THE ERINYES
text: The speedy flames of the sun and the moon's glow cannot arouse life's delights without your aid, neither can the excellence of wisdom, as well as the virtue and the joy in bold enterprise and in the sleekness of fair youth.

title: HYMN Ο΄. TO THE ERINYES
text: Upon the races of all men that remain countless, you gaze as the eye of Dike, ever in charge of justice.

spans.text: the races of all men that remain countless

title: HYMN Ο΄. TO THE ERINYES
text: O snake-haired and many-shaped goddesses of fate, change my thoughts of life into gentle and soft ones.

spans.text: change my thoughts of life into gentle and soft ones

title: HYMN ΟΑ΄. TO THE EUMENIDES
text: Hear me and be gracious, O renowned Eumenides, O pure daughters of the great Chthonic Zeus and of lovely Persephone, fair-tressed maiden.

title: HYMN ΟΑ΄. TO THE EUMENIDES
text: Over the lives of impious mortals you keep a careful eye, in charge of Necessity, you punish the unjust.

title: HYMN ΟΑ΄. TO THE EUMENIDES
text: Black-skinned queens, your awesome eyes flash forth flesh-eating darts of light.

title: HYMN ΟΑ΄. TO THE EUMENIDES
text: Everlasting, repugnant, frightful, sovereign, paralyzing the limbs with madness, hideous, nocturnal, fateful, snake-haired, terrible maidens of the night, it is you I summon to bring me holiness of mind.

title: HYMN ΟΒ΄. TO MELINOE
text: I call upon Melinoe, saffron-cloaked nymph of the earth, whom revered Persephone bore by the mouth of the Kokytos river upon the sacred bed of Kronian Zeus.

spans.text: the mouth of the Kokytos river

title: HYMN ΟΒ΄. TO MELINOE
text: In the guise of Plouton Zeus tricked Persephone and through wily plots bedded her; a two-bodied specter sprang forth from Persephone's fury.

title: HYMN ΟΒ΄. TO MELINOE
text: This specter drives mortals to madness with her airy apparitions as she appears in weird shapes and strange forms, now plain to the eye, now shadowy, now shining in the darkness— all this in unnerving attacks in the gloom of night.

title: HYMN ΟΒ΄. TO MELINOE
text: O goddess, O queen of those below, I beseech you to banish the soul's frenzy to the ends of the earth, show to the initiates a kindly and holy face.

spans.text: to the ends of the earth
show to the initiates a kindly and holy face

title: HYMN ΟΓ΄. TO TYCHE
text: I summon you here through prayer, Tyche, noble ruler, gentle goddess of the roads, for wealth and possessions, I summon you as Artemis the guide, renowned and sprung from the loins of Eubouleus, your wish is irresistible.

spans.text: sprung from the loins of Eubouleus

title: HYMN ΟΓ΄. TO TYCHE
text: Funereal and delusive, you are the theme of men's songs.

title: HYMN ΟΓ΄. TO TYCHE
text: In you lies the great variety of men's livelihood: to some you grant a wealth of blessings and possessions, to others you bring evil poverty if you harbor anger against them.

spans.text: the great variety of men's livelihood
a wealth of blessings and possessions

title: HYMN ΟΓ΄. TO TYCHE
text: O goddess, I beseech you, come in kindness to my life, grant me happiness, grant me abundant wealth.

spans.text: come in kindness to my life

title: HYMN ΟΔ΄. TO DAIMON
text: I call upon Daimon, the grand and the dreaded leader, gentle Zeus, who gives birth to all, who gives livelihood to mortals.

spans.text: the grand and the dreaded leader

title: HYMN ΟΔ΄. TO DAIMON
text: Great Zeus, wide roving, avenger, king of all, giver of wealth when you enter the house in the abundance of your powers, you refresh the life of mortals worn out with toil, you possess the keys to joy and sorrow as well.

spans.text: the keys to joy and sorrow

title: HYMN ΟΔ΄. TO DAIMON
text: So, O pure and blessed one, drive painful cares away, cares that dispatch ruin to all that live throughout the whole earth, and bring a glorious end to my life, a sweet and noble one.

spans.text: cares that dispatch ruin to all that live throughout the whole earth
a glorious end to my life

title: HYMN ΟΕ΄. TO LEUKOTHEA
text: I call upon Leukothea, daughter of Kadmos, revered goddess, mighty nurturer of fair-wreathed Dionysos.

title: HYMN ΟΕ΄. TO LEUKOTHEA
text: Hearken, O goddess, O mistress of the deep-bosomed sea, you delight in waves, you are the greatest savior to mortals, on you depends the unsteady heave of seafaring ships, you alone save men from wretched death at sea, men to whom you swiftly come as welcome savior.

spans.text: you alone save men from wretched death at sea
men to whom you swiftly come as welcome savior

title: HYMN ΟΕ΄. TO LEUKOTHEA
text: O divine lady, come to the aid of well-benched ships, do kindly save them, bring upon the sea a fair tail wind to the initiates.

spans.text: come to the aid of well-benched ships
bring upon the sea a fair tail wind

title: HYMN ΟϚ΄. TO PALAIMON
text: Comrade of joyous Dionysos in the revel of the dance, you dwell in the sea's pure, restless depths.

title: HYMN ΟϚ΄. TO PALAIMON
text: I call upon you, O Palaimon, to come to these sacred rites with kindness in your heart, with joy on your youthful face, come to save your initiates on land and on sea.

title: HYMN ΟϚ΄. TO PALAIMON
text: When storms come upon ships that ever rove the seas, you alone appear incarnate to save men, to stay the harsh anger over the briny swell.

title: HYMN ΟΖ΄. TO THE MUSES
text: Daughters of Mnemosyne, daughters of thundering Zeus, Pierian Muses, renowned and illustrious, many-shaped and beloved of the mortals you visit, you give birth to unblemished virtue in every discipline, you nourish the soul, you set thought aright as you become leaders, as you become mistresses of the mind's power.

spans.text: many-shaped and beloved of the mortals
become mistresses of the mind's power

title: HYMN ΟΖ΄. TO THE MUSES
text: Sacred and mystic rites you taught to mortals, Kleio, Euterpe, Thaleia, Melpomene, Terpsichore, Erato, Polymnia, Ourania, mother Kalliope, mighty goddess Hagne.

title: HYMN ΟΖ΄. TO THE MUSES
text: Do come to the initiates, O goddesses, in your manifold holiness, do bring glory and emulation that is lovely and sung by many.

spans.text: that is lovely and sung by many

title: HYMN ΟΗ΄. TO MNEMOSYNE
text: I call upon queen Mnemosyne, Zeus' consort, who gave birth to the holy, the sacred, the clear-voiced Muses.

title: HYMN ΟΗ΄. TO MNEMOSYNE
text: Evil oblivion that harms the mind is alien to her who gives coherence to the mind and soul of mortals.

spans.text: who gives coherence to the mind and soul of mortals

title: HYMN ΟΗ΄. TO MNEMOSYNE
text: She increases men's power, their ability to think, sweet and vigilant, she reminds us of all the thoughts we store forever in our breasts, never straying and ever rousing the mind to action.

spans.text: she reminds us of all the thoughts we store forever in our breasts
ever rousing the mind to action

title: HYMN ΟΗ΄. TO MNEMOSYNE
text: O blessed goddess, for the initiates stir the memory of the sacred rite, ward off oblivion from them.

title: HYMN ΟΘ΄. TO DAWN
text: Hear, O goddess, you bring the light of day to mortals, resplendent Dawn, you blush throughout the world, messenger of the great, the illustrious Titan.

title: HYMN ΟΘ΄. TO DAWN
text: Murky, dark, journeying night you send below the earth when you arrive; mortal men you lead to work as you tend to their lives.

spans.text: as you tend to their lives

title: HYMN ΟΘ΄. TO DAWN
text: The race of mortal men delights in you, no one escapes your sight as you look down from on high, when from your eyelids you shake off sweet sleep, when there is joy for every mortal, for every reptile, for animals, for birds, for the broods the sea contains.

spans.text: you look down from on high
there is joy for every mortal
for the broods the sea contains

title: HYMN ΟΘ΄. TO DAWN
text: All blessings that come from work are your gift.

title: HYMN ΟΘ΄. TO DAWN
text: Goddess, blessed and pure, give more sacred light to the initiates.

title: HYMN Π΄. TO THEMIS
text: I call upon pure Themis, daughter of noble Sky and Earth, Themis the young, the lovely-faced maiden, the first to show mortals the holy oracle as prophetess of the gods in her Delphic hideaway on Pythian ground where Python was king.

spans.text: daughter of noble Sky and Earth

title: HYMN Π΄. TO THEMIS
text: You taught lord Phoibos the art of giving laws.

title: HYMN Π΄. TO THEMIS
text: Amid reverence and honor you shine in the night, for you were first to teach men holy worship, howling to Bacchos in nights of revelry; from you come the honors of the gods, the honors of the holy mysteries.

spans.text: first to teach men holy worship
howling to Bacchos in nights of revelry
the honors of the holy mysteries

title: HYMN Π΄. TO THEMIS
text: O blessed maiden, come in a joyous, in a kindly spirit to your very sacred, to your mystical rites.

title: HYMN ΠΑ΄. TO BOREAS
text: Freezing Boreas, your wintry breezes make the world's lofty air quiver, come from snowy Thrace!

title: HYMN ΠΑ΄. TO BOREAS
text: Dissolve the rebellious alliance of clouds and moist air, turn the water to rushing drops of rain, bring fair weather everywhere, brighten Ether's face as the sun's rays shine upon the earth.

spans.text: Dissolve the rebellious alliance of clouds and moist air

title: HYMN ΠΒ΄. TO ZEPHYROS
text: Western breezes born of the open sea, ethereal wonders, as you blow gently your whisper brings rest from toil.

title: HYMN ΠΒ΄. TO ZEPHYROS
text: Vernal, meadow-haunting, you are loved by harbors because to ships you bring a gentle passage, soft light wind.

title: HYMN ΠΒ΄. TO ZEPHYROS
text: Come in a generous spirit, blow in unblemished ways, O airy, O invisible, O light-winged ones.

title: HYMN ΠΓ΄. TO NOTOS
text: Quickly leaping through the moist air as both of your swift wings vibrate, O father of rain, come, riding the southern clouds.

title: HYMN ΠΓ΄. TO NOTOS
text: Zeus did grant you this lofty prerogative: to send the rain-giving clouds from sky to earth.

title: HYMN ΠΓ΄. TO NOTOS
text: For this we pray to you, O blessed one, take delight in our sacrifice, do send fruit-nourishing rains to mother Earth.

title: HYMN ΠΔ΄. TO OKEANOS
text: I summon Okeanos, ageless, eternal father, begetter of immortal gods, begetter of mortal men.

title: HYMN ΠΔ΄. TO OKEANOS
text: Your waves, O Okeanos, gird the boundaries of the earth.

title: HYMN ΠΔ΄. TO OKEANOS
text: From you come all the seas, from you come all the rivers, from you come the pure, the flowing waters of earth's springs.

spans.text: the pure, the flowing waters of earth's springs

title: HYMN ΠΔ΄. TO OKEANOS
text: Hear me, O blessed god, O highest, O divine purifier, where you end the earth ends, the pole begins where ships glide on, come, grant favor, grant grace to the initiates.

spans.text: where you end the earth ends

title: HYMN ΠΕ΄. TO HESTIA
text: Queen Hestia, daughter of mighty Kronos, mistress of ever-burning fire, you dwell in the center of the house.

spans.text: you dwell in the center of the house

title: HYMN ΠΕ΄. TO HESTIA
text: May you raise the holy initiates in these sacred rites, may you grant them unwithering youth, wealth as well, prudence and purity.

title: HYMN ΠΕ΄. TO HESTIA
text: Home of the blessed gods, men's mighty buttress, eternal, many-shaped, beloved, grass-yellow, smile, O blessed one, kindly accept these offerings, waft upon us prosperity, breathe upon us gentle-handed health.

title: HYMN ΠϚ΄. TO SLEEP
text: Sleep, you are lord of all, lord of blessed gods and of mortal men, of every living thing the broad earth nurtures, for you alone are master of all, you do visit all, binding their bodies with fetters unforged.

title: HYMN ΠϚ΄. TO SLEEP
text: You free us of cares, you offer sweet respite from toil, you grant holy solace to our every sorrow, you save souls by easing them into the thought of Death, since to Death and Oblivion you are a true brother.

spans.text: you offer sweet respite from toil
you grant holy solace to our every sorrow
you save souls by easing them into the thought of Death

title: HYMN ΠϚ΄. TO SLEEP
text: But, O blessed one, I beseech you to come sweet-tempered, to be a kindly savior of the initiates, that they may serve the gods.

title: HYMN ΠΖ΄. TO DREAM
text: I call upon you, blessed, long-winged, baneful Dream, messenger of things to come, greatest prophet to mortals.

title: HYMN ΠΖ΄. TO DREAM
text: In the quiet of sweet sleep you come silent, you speak to the soul, you rouse men's minds, in their sleep you whisper the will of the gods; silent you come to show the future to silent souls that walk the noble path of devotion to the gods.

spans.text: silent you come to show the future
the noble path of devotion to the gods

title: HYMN ΠΖ΄. TO DREAM
text: Good always wins the race in people's minds, good leads their lives to pleasures anticipated, to a respite from suffering, that god himself may reveal the firmament of the divine lords through vows and sacrifices.

title: HYMN ΠΖ΄. TO DREAM
text: The end to which the pious come is always so sweeter, but to the impious never does a dreamy phantom, a prophet of evil deeds, reveal future need so that they may find the cure from pain to come.

spans.text: the end to which the pious come
the cure from pain to come

title: HYMN ΠΖ΄. TO DREAM
text: But, O blessed one, I beg you, show me the behests of the gods, in all things bring me close to the path that is straight, do not through weird apparitions show me evil signs.

title: HYMN 88΄. TO DEATH
text: Hear me, you who steer the path of all mortals and give sacred time to all from whom you are distant.

spans.text: you who steer the path of all mortals

title: HYMN 88΄. TO DEATH
text: Your sleep tears the soul free from the body's hold, whenever you undo nature's powerful bonds, bringing the long slumber, the endless one, to the living.

spans.text: tears the soul free from the body's hold
whenever you undo nature's powerful bonds

title: HYMN 88΄. TO DEATH
text: Common to all, you are unjust to some, when you bring swift end to youthful life at its peak.

title: HYMN 88΄. TO DEATH
text: In you alone is executed the verdict common to all, for to entreaties and to prayers you alone are deaf.

title: HYMN 88΄. TO DEATH
text: O blessed one, with pious vows, with sacrifices, I beg you, I pray to you, grant me long life, that old age might be a noble prize among men.
